course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Enjoyment of Classical Music
course.description: From the power and beauty of the orchestra to masterpieces of the church and concert hall, students will gain an in-depth appreciation for the history and fundamentals of Western classical music. The listening and analytical skills demonstrated will bring about a deeper understanding of music as an art form. Previous musical training, albeit helpful, is not required.

reviews.author: DavidChu
reviews.title: Good for people who loved Classical Music.
reviews.comment_content:
1. Quite disappointed as the course not too focus on listening "classical" music composed by famous composers such as Chopin, Lizst, Mozart, Debussy. Many of these famous composers only cover with 1 or 2 pieces.

2. Personally think too much time talking about Drama, Opera. Maybe others like watching dramas, but not me. It would be best if a new course can separate Instrumental music and Drama.

3. Nearly 40-50% of the time of the whole course talking about music around the Middle Age, medieval period. To be honest, those music for church chanting are boring. I can hardly distinguish the period of those songs. Those Church songs are really not my cup of tea, many of us sleep during the class.

4. A few interesting style of music such as Experimental Music, are covered during 20th centuries. But i am really really unsatisfied as JAZZ, BLUES and not covered at this course.

5. The course can really change the way I enjoy music, the background of the composers, the story behind the piece, basic techniques of music, it open a new for me enjoy music.
reviews.comment_teaching: I like Tommasini. I can see he really put effort on this course. He does the  preparation well, often provides information more than the powerpoint. Sometimes he would ask us to learn basic   music techniques, such as singing and clapping. Really relaxing during the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
- No need good music background, question always asked where composers are born. Name of the piece. Who compose it.

- For someone who are good to remembering things, VERY GOOD GRADE.

- For me, BAD GRADE.

-Absolute Grading, nothing more to say
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too many thing to do.

- 5 Self test ( Just look at the PDF while doing it.)
- Yeah mid term exam basic stuff.

- CONCERT REPORT

reviews.author: Jaymi
reviews.title: great course !!!!
reviews.comment_content:
- this is my fav course of the semester
- history of classical music, spanning across medieval era, renaissance, baroque, classical period, romantic, and 20th century
- no music background needed, this is not relevant for the exams
- if you're a classical music lover, you're gonna enjoy this course since it is pretty stress free
- a few classical pieces (and opera) are introduced, you'll listen to music in class, only those will be included in exams
- if anything, it's good to unwind to classical music
reviews.comment_teaching:
- prof tommasini is professional and nice
- his teaching is great and easy to follow and understand
- random attendance is taken through iPRS
- you can watch the lecture recap online
- (dies irae will play in a 24/7 loop in your head though)
reviews.comment_grading:
- only requires hard memorization to ace the exams
- 5 online quizzes, one for each topic and 40 MC questions per quiz - you can find quiz answers on quizlet and google

- around 80 MC questions and 30 listening MC questions
- for listening Qs, you'll need to listen to a short excerpt of a piece, recognize the piece and answer Qs based on it
- for this ^ i recommend creating a playlist and basically brainwashing yourself into remembering each song
- also do remember the birthplace of the composers

- ABSOLUTE grading !!!

- midterm : 80/86
- final : 125/140
- concert report : 13/15
- quizzes : all full mark

got an A-
reviews.comment_workload:
- quizzes for each topic, not too hard as there is a loose time limit
- a 600-700 word concert report, you have to go to a classical music concert and write a report relevant to it
- as a lot memorization is needed, there will be an added workload, i basically revised after each lecture throughout the semester

reviews.author: I love ust <3<3
reviews.title: HUMA 1102 - Enjoyment of Dies Irae
reviews.comment_content:
Content covered from the Dark Ages music to 20th century music, including operas, symphonies and etc.
For me, music from the Dark Ages to the Romantic Period is not bad, but those musical works from the 20th century are really disaster, such as "Come Out" by Steve Reich.
Not any music background is required, but it will be better for understanding the content if you have.
-
And you will listen to Dies Irae from the first class to the Romantic Period, Tommasini loves Dies Irae soooooo much !
reviews.comment_teaching:
For me, Tommasini is quite boring, i just go to class for attendance and do my own stuffs during classes.
-
Usually the first 30mins of the classes are talking about those irrelevant stuffs from the content, like "XXX concert will be held in HK on DDMMYY", "self-test X will begin at tonight 8pm, remember to finish it before it is ended, if you have any problems regarding the self-test, contact Rod before the self-test period is ended".
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
Just memorize everything in the ppt is ok, including "the place where the composer was born", "the song is composed in which year (memorize the song is composed in which period is ok)" and those music terms.
-
Most of the questions in exam are taken from the self-tests that have been done before, just look at it before exams.
-
For self-tests, the mean is very high because you can finish them at home, look at the ppt when you are doing it.
-
Concert report
Grading for the concert report is quite good, put some musical terms in ppt into your essay and you will get a satisfactory grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 self-tests on canvas, 3 of which don't have a time limit and the rest have time limit.
But it's ok, just search the keywords from the questions in ppt or simply google it can finish them.
Also, the audio files of those songs in self-tests will be uploaded on canvas before the start of self-test, you can listen to it and search for the songs on youtube before you start doing the test so you will be able to finish the it within the time limit.
-
Concert report (15% of grade)
Just look at those technical analyzes about the pieces you have chosen on the internet and rewrite it in your own words with those musical terms in the ppt. You can also express your own feeling about the pieces when you got nothing to write about anymore.
The concert report for this course is quite easy among all music courses, your report could be done without a strong technical analysis but with satisfactory grade.

reviews.author: RL
reviews.title: HUMA1102
reviews.comment_content: Study a myriad of songs across all generations since medieval, remember 50-70 songs' background, information are needed for midterm and final exam. People with basic music theory can get advantage among the class.
reviews.comment_teaching: Excellent professor with passion and his teaching is very easy to follow.
reviews.comment_grading: There is a rumour: Total marks of this course below 70% would get D/F, 70-85% C...Think twice before you take this course.
reviews.comment_workload: This course's workload is not heavy, just need to remember songs before the exams. The online-quiz in canvas is not been calculated to entire course grade. Remember to spare time for this course's revision before exam.

reviews.author: khlau
reviews.comment_content: The course covers music knowledge and history from medieval times to contemporary music. At first I thought we will be focusing on classical periods mainly as the course title states but that apparently isn't the case. To my surprise the content isn't too boring at all. However students with musical background do have an advantage in learning.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor and TA present in lessons. However the TA is only responsible for marking attendance. And I find it quite irritating to open the cam in which the professor insists to know that 'we are really here'. Discussions are encouraged and the atmosphere is good. Sometimes the professor would point out some fun facts about some composers and overall the teaching is not bad.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes(MC)x6 on reading assignments 25%
Extended quizzes(MC) (x2 â†’12.5% each) 25%
Final paper (comparative listening assignment) 35%
Attendance & participation 15%

Zoom teaching adopted this semester. Thus all the quizzes are openbook. But it takes some time for me to find the relevant content from the powerpoints. All quizzes are held in lesson. However we didn't receive the grades for final paper. Eventually got B+ (should have got A- if I didn't make some careless mistakes in the quizzes.)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is moderate. Reading materials are provided but I think they are useless in terms of taking the quizzes. Just memorize important musical terms and dates should be enough when taking the quizzes. For the final paper, the TA would allocate 2 different music pieces for everyone of us, 750 minimum words needed. But you would find out that it takes more words to describe what you want to point out. Professor emphazizes on the choice of words and grammar before hand.

reviews.comment_teaching:
âœ… Instructor was passionate and energetic in giving the lectures. He spoke clear English and often use the piano, whiteboard, and singing to explain some musical concepts

âœ… There were well-illustrated and colorful PowerPoint

âœ… After the suspension of class, he recorded lectures for us. For the final exam, he gave flexible arrangement and made the online exam available for a week so you may finish it according to your own schedule

âŒ However, i thought sometime he focus on a particular slide or music for too long so he may not able to catch up the tentative schedule of the class

reviews.comment_workload:
5 Online quiz to be completed and most of the answers can be found on the lecture notes. However, writing a concert report is rather challenging for those who do not have a musical background. I would advise you not to use those contemporary music to finish your report as you will be difficult to find relevant information about that music on the internet.  

In my opinion, the workload is relatively light compared to other 3-credit common core course. But you have to spend substantial effort to memorize the information in the lecture slides in order to get a good grade.

reviews.author: INCOGNITO
reviews.title: Remember to attend all lessons
reviews.comment_content: The syllabus covers pieces from the dark ages to the 20th century. Most genres of classical music would be taught. The stuff are quite interesting to be honest yet I think Tommansini has put too much emphasis on operas.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tommasini is great to be fair despite his fetish in opera and the boring Dies Irae. He creates a great studying atmosphere by singing, playing the piano etc.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair, the absolute grading is quite harsh. You will have to score 98% to get an A+, at least 90% to get an A-.
I ended up with a B since I missed two lessons so I urge everyone to attend ALL the lessons as you never know when attendance will be taken. I lost 2% in attendance painfully. And please double check before you submit your quizzes since they can be crucial to your final marks when you are 1 to 2% away from A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light. 5 quizzes, 1 concert report and two exams. Remember to quickly finish the quizzes since you have only two hours to complete.
All you have to worry is the concert report since it counts 15% and you will need to apply as much music concepts as you can into it in order to get high scores.

reviews.author: log g
reviews.title: Interesting Content But Super hash grading
reviews.comment_content: This lesson is about music history from the dark age to the TWENTIETH CENTURY ART MUSIC, With a wide range of music.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lesson are interesting if you know how to enjoy music.
However, many people may find it quite boring instead
reviews.comment_grading:
Every point in the power point will appear on the test and mid term and final.

He could ask you anything from content of the opera to the name of the composer.
therefore the grading is super hash
and All the test are in MC form

Attendance will be taken for 10 times randomly

Final Exam        40%
Mid-Term Exam        25%
IC2016 Report        15%
Online Quizzes        10%

A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
reviews.comment_workload:
6 self test,
one midterm
one final
one concert report

quite light workload

reviews.author: tjr1234
reviews.title: course for music history, not music nor history
reviews.comment_content:
In the beginning, I thought it is a music course, and teach me music theory and chords and blablabla. But it turns out that the course lists out composers' and pieces' names wtf. It focuses more on music history. Maybe I go for the wrong course lol, should do huma2104 instead.

PS I have G8 piano with merit and G8 music theory. I think it is a plus for this course, but not a very BIG advantage.
reviews.comment_teaching:
prof has a great passion for music and uses many examples to demonstrate the phrases in ppt. Sometimes play the piano to show us sth and it was quite fun. Tell jokes and great. Overall nice

btw u can see other students practice in lesson, they just hold their violin and guitar then practice, u know many students take this course are usually music lovers, or at least able to play music instruments, so don't feel too bad if u are not.
reviews.comment_grading:
abs grading, just read others for details.

Get a B. I have totally no idea about grading. I once calculated my total score and it was supposed to be a B+, but I was late for the concert report for 7 hours since I remember the incorrect due date. idk if the mark is deducted or not but somehow weird.
reviews.comment_workload:
Sometimes do quizzes with around 5 MCQ every time. Have mt and final quiz also and count for higher %.
Very light workload. Just go through ppt and the listening materials and u will be fine. Quiz with your friends and then u will get a high mark, no problem.

reviews.author: DanielKim9
reviews.comment_content:
This class teaches about the history of classical music ranging from:
1. The Baroque period
2. Classical period
3. Medieval period
4. Renaissance period
5. Romantic period
6. Twentieth Century
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor tries to entertain the class by letting you listen to music and tried to make you more involved by making you clap to beats and etc. However, the tests are based on the powerpoints, so you honestly don't need to listen to the lecture, just memorize everything on the powerpoints.
reviews.comment_grading:
This class is not relative grading so you are basically graded on how well you do.
I got 100% on all the self tests.
97/100 on midterm
139/150 on final
13.5/15 on concert report

My final grade was an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. Just memorize powerpoints for the exams, attend one concert, and write a report.

reviews.author: Teostra
reviews.title: Quite good course
reviews.comment_content: Content is about the history of classical music starting from the Medieval Period, Renaissance Period, Baroque Period, Classical Period, Romantic Period, until the 20th Century. In my opinion, there are many materials to memorize for in the exam, especially where you should memorize all the songs because they are all covered in the exam. Prepare to cram up your ears on the night before the exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Tommasini is a very enthusiastic teacher, he mastered all the lessons he taught and frequently gave the students examples by playing the music on the piano. Additionally, his teacher was also clear that I can always review the materials without viewing the lecture videos on canvas.

The TAs will provide a playlist for students to use, both for the midterm exam and the final exam. Students having problems with the quizzes or grading may contact the TAs. I got a problem related to my final exam grade, and they all responded quickly and the problem was solved immediately.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam (133/140)       40%
Mid-Term Exam  (81/86)     25%
Concert Report   (13/15)   15%
Online Quizzes    (10/10)    10%
Attendance    (10/10)    10%

Luckily I got an A (which is a quite good score for me)

In my opinion, as long as you master the slides and presentation given my Prof Tommasini, you can get good marks in the exams, as some questions are similar or even the same with the quizzes given.

There are listening questions for the exams, for the midterm, there are 6 listening questions (which each consist of 4 more questions), and for the final exam there were 15 listening questions (which each consist of 4 more questions)

The midterm exam consists of the materials starting from the start of the term until midterm.

The final exam consists of the materials starting after the midterm exam until the end. (Non-cumulative)
reviews.comment_workload: The course grade will consist of 1 midterm exam, 1 concert report, quizzes on canvas, and 1 final exam. The workload is pretty light in my opinion, but some may face some problems with the concert report since you are required to attend a concert, either it is from HKUST or outside HKUST.

reviews.author: captmarvin
reviews.comment_content:
At the first lecture of the course, the lecturer emphasized that music knowledge is not needed for this course. Well, after the course, I may have to clarify that students with only a few music knowledge are welcomed, but it is true that they must have to work much harder.

In this course, music and operas from the Middle Age to the 20th Century will be introduced. There are a lot of music terms you need to remember. You will listen to masterpieces of famous musicians, and memorize the techniques used in the pieces of work, as the may be asked in the exams.

Last but not least, you have to participate in 6 sessions of the Intimacy of Creativity events, including 4 open discussions and 2 concerts. The songs you listen to are all from composers from the 1900s (and some of them are still alive!). In my experience, I have no idea what the composers are trying to show us but I have to try my best to analyze the songs using things that are taught in the lecture, and present it as an essay. Fortunately, the lecturer doesnâ€™t ask for very detailed analysis and it is not difficult to get a good result.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecturer is professional. He encourages us to participant in the lecture instead of listening to what he says only. You can also listen to songs during the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam  40%
Mid-term Exam  25%
IC Concert Report  15%
Online Quizzes  10%
Attendance  10%

Both final exam and mid-term exam are multiple choice questions. About 60% are questions that ask you the basic knowledge you have learned from the lectures. And for the remaining 40%, you have to recognize songs from the masterpieces that are introduced to you during the lectures and answer the characteristics such as the names, the composers and the techniques of the songs. For students who are good at music, it may be a piece of cake. But I am pretty sure that most student have to use much more time to memorize the songs.

There are 5 MC question online quizzes at all. Each of them asks questions about music in 1-2 periods. They are open book quizzes so most students get high marks.

Lecture attendance will be taken 4 times randomly after the add/drop period. And the attendance will be also taken at the 6 sessions of the Intimacy of Creativity. For each additional absence, you will have 1% deducted from your attendance grade. So you are suggested to participate in all events of the course.

You have to write a 500-600 words essay about the experience during the Intimacy of Creativity. Knowledge taught in the lecture is needed to be included. As I mentioned before, it is not difficult if you are willing to work hard.

Absolute grading. You have to get at least 90% in the exams in order to get an A.
A+  98â€“100%
A  92â€“97.99%
A-  90â€“91.99%
B+  88â€“89.99%
B  82â€“87.99%
B-  80â€“81.99%
C+  78â€“79.99%
C  72â€“77.99%
C-  70â€“71.99%
D  60â€“69.99%
F  0â€“59.99%
reviews.comment_workload: Online quizzes, mid-term, concert report, final examâ€¦ Moderate workload. And if you like music, you may think it is a kind of relaxation as you will listen to music during the lecture.

reviews.author: ip
reviews.comment_content: Covered all musical periods including Dark Ages music to 20th century, from instrumental music to operas basically everything. You may find the music in Dark ages and Renaissance Period unfamiliar. They are not my cup of tea in fact. However, you may find it interesting afterwards as the songs and features were reused in later years. You will hear Dies Irae throughout the whole semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: He's lively with teaching patterns of introducing the type of music, songs that belong to that type, the techniques of songs and characteristics of composers including where he was born. It might be boring sometimes but never mind as lecture vids are always provided.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading as long as you have basic music background and good memory.


Absolute grading (see other reviews)

Stat for reference:
midterm 87/100 (25%)
final 144/149 ( 40%)
concert report 13/15 (15%)
quiz 10/10 (10%)
attendance 10/10 (10%)
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
For midterm and final, there are roughly 50 songs each for you to remember. You have to know which period they belong to, the form of the piece (eg rondo form, ABA form etc), the movement of the piece, where the composer is born, the plot etc (everything in lecture notes) Questions are straightforward and are in MC form, mostly taken in quizzes and revision files.

For concert report, you have to apply music terms and stuff learnt in lessons. You should have a focused thesis statement. Don't worry you can send your thesis statement before that to the professor and he will amend it for you.

Studying in spring semester, you have to attend 2 IC concerts which will be held during weekends and 4 IC discussions held during normal school time. During the two weeks IC events, lectures are cancelled so it evens out.

Conclusion: prior knowledge on music and good memory is required to score high easily. As it is absolute grading, it doesn't matter how low the mean is. (the mean is roughly C range/ B- I forgot)

reviews.author: mattthewcyh
reviews.comment_content: The course covers the history of music from the timeline, with the four musical periods. Professor strongly asserts the importance of Dies Irae, and asked students to sing along.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Tommasini can explain all the concepts and musical terms clearly so all of us understand. The lesson is also quite interactive, as he may ask students to sing together for a song, or clap some metrical patterns. Good for the ones who love watching all kinds of concert vids and performances since they will be played all the time.
reviews.comment_grading: Looks like absolute grading. Unless you are very confident about your music knowledge, don't expect too much for an A. Exams are relatively straight forward so everybody get a good mark. But the concert report needs some preparation and work, otherwise it will be a problem of the whole grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Horrible. I don't understand why music has so much work to do, with all those online quizzes and self test. Those tests are not difficult but they just consume too much time.

reviews.author: Hamburger Milk
reviews.title: GOOD TEACHING & CONTENT
reviews.comment_content: interesting and well organised
reviews.comment_teaching: good and inspiring
reviews.comment_grading:
absolute grading scale
A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
B+ 88 â€“ 89.99%
B 82 â€“ 87.99%
B- 80 â€“ 81.99%

C 72 â€“ 77.99%
C- 70 â€“ 71.99%
D 60 â€“ 69.99%
F 0 â€“ 59.99%

I think it's VERY HARD to get A or A+ for a person who has never studied music before and knows little about classical music.
reviews.comment_workload:
The online quizzes are very easy and have a long time limit.

The exams are quite similar with the quizzes. But they are harder because they are closed-book with no notes. So be well prepared.

The attendance will be taken 10 times randomly through out the semester after the add/drop period.

I think the concert report is not so difficult as it heard but it's not easy to get high score.

reviews.author: iwantarange
reviews.title: Interesting, and grade is proportional to effort
reviews.comment_content:
Music ranging from medieval times to 20th century inclusively, with a variety of genres that you may know/not know about, including piano pieces, opera and other things. For those having musical instruments/piano background, they will find certain parts (especially those in Classical period) quite easy to handle.
The pieces picked by this course sound good in general, but do note that some 20th century music may let you feel annoyed as you may not be able to adapt to those styles.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Tommasini pays a lot of effort and passion in teaching, and you will enjoy in the music played during the class. Sometimes he may also play the piano himself.
As you may know, this course requires a concert report. Professor Tommasini will discuss some thesis statements during class to make students familiar of them, and he is willing to read and amend your thesis statement if you send him an email.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course employs the University absolute grading system, for details you can check easily via Google.
Grading:
25% Midterm (60 knowledge-based+40 listening questions in 1 hour)
40% Final exam (70 knowledge-based+80 listening questions in 1.5 hours)
15% Concert report (500~600 words)
10% Self tests (Open-book, each one with a certain time limit)
10% Attendence
Given that most students can get nearly full marks in self tests and attendence, there is only 80% that you need to pay some effort. The harder you study, the higher score you will get. The questions in exams may (largely) similar to the questions in self tests or some revision tests. Also, pay some effort in your concert report and do the requirements in the marking rubics may help with your score. I just followed the rubics and I got a decent score in the concert report.
Concerning the effort required, I would say getting B range is generally possible if you have gone through the notes, music and self-tests, but getting an A range requires much more effort even if you have some music background.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate~a little heavy workload. The workload is mainly contributed by concert report and revision before exams. Having perfect pitch surely reduces your workload as you can easily distinguish between different pieces.
Here is a link which may help you during your revision, containing pieces discussed during classes: https://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=huma1102
(I used the playlist by rodyu, who is the TA in this course.)

reviews.author: I Want 1st Hon!
reviews.title: For Music Lovers ONLY!
reviews.comment_content:
Quite Broad since it is all about history.
A bit narrow for introducing composers and their backgrounds.
I don't think it is a good idea for him to teach the nearly the whole music history and finish it. Instead, more details should be covered. It doesn't seem like you can learn things in detail.
Personally, I don't think it is neither a well-made course nor a badly made course.
For you music lovers like me, you may feel disappointed like me...Though you can still learn something. Definitely give a "C"!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Despite the fact that the content is not great and grade is quite harsh, you can feel the royalty/power of music. You can really love music if you enjoy his teaching.

Though, professor arrives just on time, and makes announcement + PRS for more than 20 minutes, once 35 minutes!!! This makes me feel disappointed.

He has taught well, and Powerpoint is well made.  However, the time management of class teaching is not so well done...

He explains the concert report and uses student example with his revision very detailed and clear, which is one of the greatest things I learn from him.

Anyway, you can really enjoy music since you can listen to a few listening videos each lesson and you can sing or clap in some of the lectures.

SIT in the front if you love music!
Professor is not happy about people being noisy at the back. Pay your RESPECT!
reviews.comment_grading:
10 Random PRS (10%), I attend all PRS. Mean: 8.7, Highest: 10, Lowest: 0

CLASSICAL Concert Report (15%) (a kind of average workload: assignment): 1% deducted if you cannot prove that you have attended the concert, evidence? KEEP all concert materials till the last day! I get 12 out of 15.
Mean: 11.6, Highest:15, Lowest: 9.5

5 Self tests (each 2%): 40 questions for you to practice. Remember to check ALL the answers correct before submitting! I am careless for the first two self tests and I get 35/39 in both tests, though I get full marks in the next 3 tests. (9.59%)

25% midterm exam: 93/100,
Mean: 75.9, Highest: 99, Lowest: 26, SD ~15. (23.25%)

40% final exam: 142/150 (37.87%)
Mean: 122.1, Highest 146, Lowest 53

Total: 10+12+9.59+23.25+37.87= 92.71
Grade: A
90-91.99% will give you an A-. I just repeatedly checked my final exam questions, and luckily got an A.

Absolute grading: Hard to get good grade for lazy people. Easy to get B range or above if you love music & go through all details & MAKE a revised notes. Meanwhile, you may fall into traps that you can carelessly get a C range.
Hence, it depends your careful preparations in Fall semester! I don't know spring semester though...
90-100% A range
80-89.99% B range
reviews.comment_workload:
Better make yourself a revised note after every lesson, though it takes time...
You don't want to go through ~50-70 ppt slides each lecture. IF cumulative, you have over 800 slides...
I actually put more time on LANG1002. The workload is more and more less than LANG1002.
Though you must keep track of the professor's teaching.

reviews.author: Ada0120
reviews.title: Good instructor, bad grade
reviews.comment_content: If you are a classical music lover, then the course is perfect for you. Very interesting content. The professor added in some fun facts about each composers, so that the course would not be only about the music they composed.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is humorous and is very passionate towards teaching. He is willing to answer any questions raised by students, either during lessons or in the email. He also talked about these question in class, so that everyone could think about the answers.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since it's an absolute grading course, the grade I got was not that good. You need to get at least 90% of the mark to get an A-. Unfortunately I only got 86%, so I got a B instead. Do think twice if you want a good grade. If you insist on taking the course, I suggest that you take it during year 1, so that the mark will be halved and does less effect on your GPA.

The professor will take attendance any time he wants (e.g. at the beginning, middle, or the end of the lessons) and he will not take attendance every lesson. If you want to skip lesson, make sure that you know someone that is taking the class and will tell you the code for taking attendance. Or else just make it to class.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not really heavy. There are 5 online quizzes to do, and a concert report to finish.The online quizzes are not very difficult, but do try to get them all correct, cause it will be harder to get high marks in your exam. As for the concert report just try to apply what the professor said during lessons, then it should be fine.

reviews.author: TheBestReview
reviews.title: Never study in Spring
reviews.comment_content:
From medieval to 20th century, the contents are comprehensive. The composers and pieces are mostly popular and expected to be covered.
Students without any classical music background may find the musical works in medieval/renaissance/20th century a bit strange but you should be able to understand. Basic musical terms will be introduced but they are really basic, I mean you won't find it difficult to answer the questions regarding musical terms or knowledge in midterm or final.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor has great presentation skill and knows where to make fun. Therefore, you should be able to focus in lesson  at 9am LOL
He did play piano in every lesson so it may be something attractive for you to attend the lesson (Also PRS)
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair
Both Midterm and final are MCs
Above 0.5 SD in Midterm
No data in Final (With my approximation, I got around 85%-90% correct of the questions)
Grade: A-
Having musical background helps you a bit for understanding
Unless you are really familiar with classical music, make sure you have memorized all the contents
I have some backgrounds but as I am lazy, my midterm doesn't go that well with my expectation
reviews.comment_workload:
LMES self test (Doesn't really count just finish it)
PRS (You never know when you need)
Midterm, Final (All MC)

INTIMACY OF CREATIVITY 2015
You must attend open discussions by different modern composers
Modern? YES, MODERN
If you are those people only enjoy music from Baroque to Romantic like me, you may dislike modern music
Remember you need to write concert reports for those music, which means you have to attend the concert from those composers!

How to skip IC2015? Easy enough, it only appears in SPRING so please study this course in FALL

GLHF

reviews.author: Jocely_chan
reviews.comment_content:
from other comments
It contains musical terms like motet which is the content of grade 8 music theory...
reviews.comment_teaching: he will blow water according to the powerpoint. But it will be very boring and confusing for those who have no music background(like me...)
reviews.comment_grading:
from other comments

My final score was extremely low(50%) and I finally get a C grade in this rubbish common core.
reviews.comment_workload:
each week have either a review quiz or a listening quiz.
The review quiz is done online and I suggest asking all of it in chatgpt instead of doing it on your own,
Listening quiz each time about a 10-songs playlist which will be given a list of composers and songs.
Final is a disaster which requires you to write an essay given it is a cc only.

reviews.author: ç™½èŒ¶æ¨¹
reviews.title: Not a bad choice for common core
reviews.comment_content: Mainly about Western music history and the style and structure of classical music. Quite interesting if you like music, requires memorization of details taught in lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: Perfect! Best instructor ever! 9.5/10
reviews.comment_grading:
We were told that there will only be MCs, fill-in-the-blanks, and short questions in our final. But, eventually, we got long questions and 350-word essays.
Midterm: ~80%
Final: ~70%
Video essay: 100%!!!
Grade: B+
A grade higher than what I expected, as I do not know anything about music theory and do not know any musical instrument.
**Revising lectures is more important than slides. Watch lecture recordings if you do not have enough time to revise all slides.
reviews.comment_workload: Most quizzes are not difficult. Video essay requires a lot of work if you are not an expert on music structures.

reviews.author: ForeignerIvan
reviews.title: Wonderful introduction to the world of Western Classical music
reviews.comment_content:
Almost entirely about music in the Western world, from the Antiquity (~2300 BCE), Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, 20th Century, up to the Contemporary era (1950s~).

Some simple music theory (scales, chords, cadences, etc.) and a few lectures dedicated to opera was also included.

Textbook: How to Listen to Great Music: A Guide To Its History, Culture, and Heart by Robert Greenberg.
https://www.amazon.com/How-Listen-Great-Music-History/dp/0452297087#:~:text=In%20How%20to%20Listen%20to,and%20long%2Dtime%20listeners%20alike.
Prof recommended to buy and read through Kindle (which I did), but you can try and find any free version online if possible. The concepts and the examples that Prof gave follows the textbook, so I was able to revise pretty well with it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In his lectures, you will see immediately that Prof. Droscha knows what he's talking about (being the artistic director for Shaw Auditorium definitely helps). He has a sense of humor, often demonstrates the sheet music excerpts with the piano, and teaches us the deep emotional and biographical significance of pieces which we may have heard many times but that we haven't put our minds into.

The one weakness he has, apparently, is Canvas. He somehow constantly had problems with the scoring and quiz system, such as setting the deadline of the listening quiz right at the end of lecture time, and we almost always run out of time before the quiz was finished. So for everyone's sanity, don't be afraid to raise any problems you have with Canvas before the lectures. Hope that Prof can make peace with Canvas in future semesters...
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is absolute, as with any other HUMA courses. I won't list the grading scheme here as others have done so already.

1. Attendance (10%): used IPRS, taken irregularly
2. Quizzes (20%): in-class listening quizzes, online quizzes on lecture contents
3. Video Essay (20%): Attend a free concert in UST, then make a 10â€“12-minute video on one of the pieces. Graded out of 50.
4. Midterm (20%): Mostly MCs, and one Q on arranging order of birth of composers
5. Final (30%): MCs, Fill-in-the-blank, Short Qs, one essay Q
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload depends on what your goals are.

Memorization and understanding of the concepts and composers should be fine for B-range.

For A ~ A+, most of the workload will be on the video essay. Since I had next to no video-editing experience, and the concert I'm interested in was held one week before the ddl, I had to start playing around with the software, collecting assets and researching before the concert. If you do put in the effort, a 46-50/50 should be easy to get.

For the essay Q in the final, knowing some important concepts and sentences for each period and being familiar with the examples in the listening quizzes will definitely help.

reviews.author: notmyname
reviews.title: harsh grading- not the best HUMA course there is
reviews.comment_content:
The content covers history and the background of different eras of music.
Baroque, Rennaissance, Medeival, Romantic, Modernism; everything from the 14th century onwards.

The professor has pretty self-explanatory lecture slides. You wouldn't necessarily need to attend class to understand what is going on. There is a textbook, but do not purchase it- it's pretty useless.

There is a lot of memorization to do especially because the content is so history heavy. Most of the class however focuses on improving your listening to classical music. To be able to actually "listen" and not just listen. After doing all the practice and attending classes, it's actually pretty easy to do .
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ilari is great, he's super passionate about music and is a musician and composer himself. Often during class he would play the piano to illustrate examples and it was beautiful.

He explains everything in large detail and is open to any kind of discussion later as well. If you're passionate about music, he would be a great mentor. Also very prompt with emails.

Also no phones/mobile devices in class. If you want to take notes, do it on paper.
reviews.comment_grading:
Horrible. Absolutely horrible. I got above mean on all the quizzes and tests, and had full percentage for attendance. I was expecting an A- at least, but got a B- instead.

The essay (35% of the grade) screwed me over. Even though I'm a native English speaker with pretty good writing skills, he said it was not 'comprehensive enough'. I'm not sure what he was looking for- but I don't care enough about classical music to write an expansive paper on Richard Wagner.

Attendance is 15% i think, and although not mandatory, does count towards final percentage. It is through IPRS, so i assume if you had a friend you could tell them to help you out.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload really. Just the quizzes which are periodical, and the final essay which is due at the end of the semester. I had to attend 2 concerts of the cosmopolis festival- which was what the essay was written about.

But there's no homework, no reading, nothing. Youre not expected to participate in class at all.

reviews.author: rk9
reviews.title: good course
reviews.comment_content: musical eras, instruments, no musical background needed (though it may help in some areas but definitely not such a huge head start). a lot of listening, make sure to check out all of the recordings given and memorize them (they usually pop up on quizzes).
reviews.comment_teaching: the professor is really passionate about what they are teaching so it was an amusing experience to learn in their class. there was never a boring session in my opinion. involves students as well though not so demanding (no right or wrong answers, mostly just how we perceive art).
reviews.comment_grading: fair grading, you get as much as you out your effort in. attendance is also graded, essay grading higher than midterm and finals quiz altogether.
reviews.comment_workload: workload spread out thoroughly, not to heavy not too light either, just the right amount for a common core course.

reviews.author: Juney2lee
reviews.comment_content:
Unlike the most students would expect (if they don't read the reviews) The content is most focused on the overall history of the classical music. You have to expect a lot of memorizing just like a typical history class would do.
It is interesting to learn, but due to online mode I had, I wasn't able to fully absorb the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor did provide his best with the ppt (Which is somewhat lengthly) with various listening materials. However, for the online mode at least, I strongly recommend not to take this course. Try this course in a real classroom which the professor should prepare well for the listening experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes(MC)x6 on reading assignments 25%
Extended quizzes (MC)
(x2 â†’12.5% each) 25%
Final paper (comparative listening assignment) 35%
Attendance & participation 15%
reviews.comment_workload:
Could be a lot, could be small depends on the preference of the student. It was quite a lot for me to memorize and write a comparative essay about two concert videos (Short clips)
For the offline mode, you would have to watch full length concerts and write about them. If you are not the guy for these methods, I suggest to avoid this course.

reviews.author: fakemusicgenius
reviews.title: Enjoyment of Classical Music "History"
reviews.comment_content:
Actually it's more like to be Enjoyment of Classical Music "History" more than Enjoyment of Classical Music. Music history is the focus and some basic musical knowledge was taught.

Topic 1:Fundamentals of Listening
Topic 2:Overview of Western Music History
Topic 3:Rhythm and Analytical Listening
Topic 4:Ars Nova (14th Century)
Topic 5:Notation of Rhythm and Pitch â€“ Melodies
Topic 6:The Renaissance
Topic 7:Early Baroque
Topic 8:Evolution of Instruments
Topic 9: Late Baroque
Topic 10:Formal Structure
Topic 11:Classicism
Topic 12:Romanticism
Topic 13:Song throughout the Ages
Topic 14:Revolutions and Music
Topic 15:Early 20th Century
Topic 16:Chronological topic VIII â€” 20th and 21st Centuries
Each topic includes some reading materials (texts/youtube vids)
reviews.comment_teaching: Fair. "History" class-the "best" way to teach is to make a ppt and read them aloud, and that's what he's doing. Sometimes it's a bit boring, but he will play some videos/ his piano and ask some questions. And you expect around 25% of lesson time are allocated to quizzes and midterms Lol
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes on reading assignments 25%
-lesson time, some conceptional stuff or identifying music (everything comes from ppt/reading materials), ~5 questions each time, one wrong answer=below mean. Quite tricky but open book

Midterm (x2, 12.5% each) 25%
-same as quizzes, but longer and it's cumulative (~20 questions each time, 2-3 wrong answers=below mean)

Term paper (concert report) 35%
-have to participate in Cosmopolis Festival (éƒ½æœƒéŸ³æ¨‚ç¯€, outside lesson time) concerts for the concert report. He likes hearing your feelings towards the melody more than the background of the piece. Will provide guidelines and sample paper

Attendance & participation 15%
-Attendance is required (cam on), can't skip lessons :(

If you have basic music background and good at memorizing stuff, HUMA1102 may be your cup of tea. At least they keep you away from bad grades

Me: Quiz overall ~3 mistakes, Midterm overall 2 mistakes, Term paper didn't release, Attendance full, got an A
reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable comparing to other 3-credit courses

1st workload: quizzes and midterms. 50% of your grade but he will only tell you the exact date and scope 1-2 lessons in advance

2nd: attendance

3rd: go concerts and write essay. Previous sem it was dead after final period

reviews.author: leavethisblank
reviews.comment_content: Plz refer to others. Don't want to mention again.
reviews.comment_teaching: quiet good, at least i understand :)
reviews.comment_grading:
absolute grading
for the grading boundaries, plz refer to others as well.
for attendance, i miss like around 1-2 classes, and i still get full mark on attendance.
and here is my marks:
1 quiz score 9 out of 10, and 1 score 7 out of 10, others full mark.
mid term full mark
video 47/50
final:
MC fill in blanks 48/50
listening 20/21
short question and essay 12/19
overall A
reviews.comment_workload:
5 listening quiz, 5 review quiz, 1 concert report (this sem video essay), mid term plus final
listening quiz:
he will play you short clips of recording (around 30s) and you have to tell the composer and title of the music from this.
listening quiz is not that hard. in this semester, he provides work bank to us so you can just remember part of the name of the artist. he advise us to listening to it daily, but i just remember them a day before the quiz, and most of them get 10/10, so i think is OK.
review quiz:
open book, mostly talk about the contents in his ppt and you can basically convert it to pdf and search the keyword.
time limited, mostly 10 mins for 10 questions, but somehow more than enough. not hard.
video essay (or videotaped version of concert report/essay):
A bit troublesome for me as no musical background.
10-12 mins of video
it can be divided into 3 parts: background of composer, background of the piece, and analysis of the piece.
the first 2 part is not difficult, basically you can search everything from internet.
the third part is the most problematic session for me. As i am talking about the form of the piece (sonata), so i am kind of inevitably need to mention the key of each session of music and it is really hard for a person that have no musical background to identify this through listening. i probably spent most of my time on looking the textbook that analyze the piece.  
Mid term and final:
an advance version and combination of listening quiz and review quiz.
the listening part includes some more question like asking you the forms of the piece, but generally are the same. not hard.
final has 1 more part that is essay, in this sem, 3 short question plus 1 long question. not many people can get the long question part's mark.

reviews.author: Edwardgun
reviews.comment_content: Content is about every musical periods from ancient times to Avant-garde(2001, this music is so weird istg). Mostly discusses about the notable composers, their notable contributions and generally good music. :D There is also a week that focuses on musical theory to help with non-musical background students.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is a really funny guy. His presentations are very detailed and straight to the point. Most of his tests' answers can be found in the presentation as well. The presentations also gives us an example of what he expects from us in terms of making an essay or the homework he assigns to us.

He also teaches really well to people that do not have any music background and does not expect that much technical musical analysis from us.

reviews.comment_workload:
Final exam is not cumulative, it only covers what is after the mid terms.

Mid-terms happen on week 6.

Video essay is the most of what this course's workload is. We were to view an online concert and make a review out of it. Reviewing the music based on the composer's biography and musical analysis of the piece. It helps if you know any good editing software(Recommend DaVinci Resolve) and listen to the content of musical analysis he gives during class.

There are two types of quizzes to help familiarize what the final and mid-term is going to be like.

The first type is a listening quiz, there are 5 in total and he makes a spotify playlist of what is going to come out. He plays a 20 sec clip of the song and we have to guess the composer, title and year. Word bank is also provided.

The second type is just MCQ of theory.

2 weekly readings that are optional that just give additional context to the composers

reviews.author: TheodoreYuen
reviews.comment_content:
Going through the history of classical music, starting from Ancient Greek Music, followed by Renaissance, Baroque Period, Classical period, Romantic Period and Post-tonal Period. The course covers the characteristic of the music in each period as well as the historical background and some composers. Opera was put aside originally and was taught later on after talking about the Romantic Period.

Quite interesting and definitely help me understand more of the music I listen to.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is enthusiastic about classical music, often demonstrating personally, especially when we are talking about Opera given that he is a baritone.

Skipping opera initially caused some problem though as we were originally going through time from the past and by the time we were introduced to opera, we have reached the chapter on the Romantic Period. We have to go back in time and caused some confusion.

5 review quizzes on the lecture notes
Just read through the notes before taking them and it should be quite easy

5 listening quizzes on music mentioned in the lecture notes
A list will be provided, just listen to the music according to the list and memorise them with some key detail mentioned in the notes will get you through

Extra tip: It's not difficult to predict what the long question would be

Analysis of a piece of your own choice, in video form. I am familiar with video editing and it helped reducing the time needed, however, it may be a bit problematic for those who never work on video editing

reviews.title: Enjoyable course by Droscha
reviews.comment_content:
Middle Age Church Music
Renaissance Music
Baroque Music
Classical Music
Opera
Romantic Music
19th century Music

A quick walk through the above musical periods to give you an overview of western music history. The lessons were fun and interesting because Prof. Droscha kept playing music recordings and sometimes playing the piano on his own to explain the concepts and ideas.

He himself is a baritone so he spent more time talking about opera. You can enjoy his singing during lectures too!
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Droscha is a very good presenter. He has a passionate delivery and his mic quality is top notch. You would feel like you are listening to a Spotify podcast.

You will never feel bored in his lectures.

But his slides can sometimes be a little messy.

reviews.author: Spring Ho
reviews.title: Do not get cocky if you know music, this is a memorization training course
reviews.comment_content:
other people posted very complete syllabus, so I will just say this:
there are two playlists on youtube, around 200 fucking videos together, and half of it is ancient songs that you would not enjoy at all, you gotta burn those in your brains. just do yourself a favor and stay out of this.
Trust me, I play the piano and I already have a better acceptance towards those music than ordinary people, and I hated it.
If I ever wanted to know which castrati can sing like a women the best, I would have already stabbed myself in the head instead.
reviews.comment_teaching:
alright he is a pretty cool guy I will give him that, some of the stuff that he does is actually quite fun (singing in class,etc.), and you can tell his passion in classical music, as a person that practice classical music also I respect that.
He tries his best to make music terms easy to understand as a lot of people who took the course does not have a musical background, so overall, he was a good lecturer.
reviews.comment_grading: it is bullshit, remember 100 songs from 200 years ago and you will still find yourself below mean. just don't try it.... I mean sure go for it. Just to clarify, I took this course 2 years ago, maybe things has changed, and I wasn't a hard worker at all, if you are willing to pour the time and effort in I am sure you will do fine.
reviews.comment_workload: actually apart from memorizing a ton of stuff, there is not much to do except for the concert report. but I will still give it a E just because how hideous it was.

reviews.author: lovestudying
reviews.comment_content:
Content is about music from the Dark Ages music to 20th century music, like  operas, symphonies and folk songs.

Most songs are quite good to listen, yet 20th Century and the Dark Ages songs are subject to personal preference ( I don't quite like it).

If you have musical background, you will find this course very easy as it covers most of the basic stuff

And you will keep listening to Dies Irae from the first class to the Romantic Period, Tommasini loves Dies Irae yet I find it very bring washing
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is quite boring and he spent around 30 mins in each lesson to recap what he taught in previous lessons.

Most people just go there and do their own stuff.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absoute grading.

For mid-term and final, it splits into two parts: the first part is theory questions. Just need to go through the ppt and pay attention to the details. The second part is listening to songs.
All the songs are taught in class. You need to be able to identify the song name, its period, its composer and some other features.
It is all in MCs and some appears in the online quizzes. Better to go through the online quizzes before midterm and final

reviews.comment_content:
Covering music from Ars Nova to 20th century.
Study a lot about history, composers and genres.

but honestly speaking, if you could memorize all those stuff, you can still get a good grade (getting a B range is not that difficult)
reviews.comment_workload:
few online quizzes
I learnt nothing abt music so I find the essay a little bit difficult for me, but the workload id still fine

Covered from Medieval Music, Renaissance Music, Classical Period Music, Romantic Music till Contemporary Art Music.

Simple music theory concepts include fundamentals of rhythm, meter, melody, elementary contrapuntal techniques, key signatures, major and minor scales, and the circle of fifths will be introduced.

reviews.author: txlhhey
reviews.title: Interesting Class if you like classical music
reviews.comment_content:
Medieval Music: discussion of Medieval culture, sacred music (including the Medieval mass and motet), and secular forms will cover the work of composers Hildegard of Bingen, Leonin, Perotin, and Machaut.

Renaissance Music: discussion of Renaissance culture, vocal music (including the Renaissance mass and motet, and madrigal), and instrumental music will include works by composers Josquin Des Prez and Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina.

Baroque Music:  in-depth analysis of the musical genres from the Baroque period will cover the work of composers Bach, Handel, Purcell, Pachelbel, Corelli, and others.  The section will begin with a discussion of the art, culture, and general philosophy of music during this time period followed by a discussion of vocal genres (oratorio, cantata, and opera) and instrumental genres (the suite, and sonata).

Classical Period Music: cover the works of Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven, focusing on the development of vocal genres (including opera) and instrumental genres (including the sonata). In addition, new genres of the concerto and symphony will be covered.

Romantic Music: The most extensive section of the semester will begin with a discussion of the chamber music of early eighteenth-century composers Schubert, Mendelssohn, Chopin, and Liszt. The section will continue with an overview of the continuing development of opera, including the work of Verdi, Puccini, and Wagner and cover new genres of ballet and program music with the works of composers Berlioz, Strauss, and Tchaikovsky.  Music from the second half of the eighteenth century will include works by late Romantic composers Brahms and Tchaikovsky, and nationalist works by Tchaikovsky, Mussorgsky, Smetana, and others.

Twentieth century and today: beginning with works by early twentieth-century composers Debussy, Ravel, Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Bartok, Schoenberg, and others.  Impressionism, neo-Romanticism, expressionism, and primitivism will be examined along with neoclassicism and 12-tone music.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TOMMASINI is funny but serious at the same time. He will reply email if you have any concerns about the lectures and the report.

Have lecture videos: very useful for revision!

reviews.author: dre.bri
reviews.comment_content: Interesting content, goes over the history of classical music from Middle Ages up to the end of the 20th century.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor goes over the slides that are quite straightforward, but nothing special. Sometimes he uses the piano and has the class sing along to help you understanding some concepts. He is very repetitive in the sense that every time he basically goes over the entire content from the previous lecture before starting with the new material. It can help you if you miss class. He takes attendance with iPRS 10 times throughout the semester which count towards your final grade. He also uploads the lecture recordings
reviews.comment_grading: Not curved, so you can figure out throughout the semester what grade range you fall in. The difficult part of the exams are the listening samples from pieces he explained in class that you need to recognize.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. You have no homework except completing the 5 open-book quizzes on canvas and the final one-page essay. In order to write the essay you will have to attend a concert event in Hong Kong. He will provide plenty of suggestions for you to go.

reviews.author: cloudherethere
reviews.comment_content:
Periods covering:
the Middle Ages
the Medieval
the Renaissance
the Romantic Period
the Baroque
Post War Period
the 20th Century
reviews.comment_teaching:
Actually he is a really passionate teacher who loves what he teaches. He even went to the concerts recommended to students. Sometimes he may get annoyed if you talk in his lessons, but basically he is a very nice person.

He will also help with the short introduction of your concert report.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is considered nice for people who are good at memorising.
You have to memorise information about the composer, like where they were born, what they died for.
Remember to memorise the music.

It is absolute grading.
If you are lazy, please just skip this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
There will be one Mid-Term Exam and one Final Exam. The Mid-Term will take place during
regularly scheduled lecture time. The Final Exam time and place will be announced later in
the semester. No make-up exams will be offered, unless an excused absence form is
submitted on time with the proper justification.

Five (5) Quizzes will be administered via CANVAS over the course of the semester to allow
students the opportunity to evaluate their progress in the course and prepare for the Mid-Term
and Final Exams. Quiz scores WILL COUNT towards the final grade in the course as outlined
below. Online Quiz 1 will be administered with NO TIME LIMIT during the 24-hour period.
Online quizzes 2-3 will have a TIME LIMIT OF 2 HOURS, and quizzes 4-5 will have a TIME
LIMIT OF 1 HOUR during the 24-hour period. No make-ups will be offered.

Students will be required to attend a classical music event taking place in Hong Kong and
write a report detailing their experiences (500-600 words). A list of event presenters is
available below, including both free and ticketed events.

Workload is not huge considering the assignment.

reviews.author: Abraham Aditya
reviews.comment_content:
Discussing about music from 6 different period
- Medieval Period
- Renaissance Period
- Baroque Period
- Classical Period
- Romantic Period
- 20th Century

Honestly, I really enjoy classical music, especially the instrumental music of Baroque and classical period. But, there is also a lot of operas from romantic that really hard to memorize. Also the music from the 20th century is very very weird. Although i don't enjoy that part, the music from 20th century is easy to memorize
reviews.comment_teaching:
Tommasini is knowledgeable about the materials and he teach them in a way we can easily understand. He is also passionate when teaching and that also affected me in the class. I really liked his way of teaching and the content of his class.

He also provided the lecture videos in canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
ABSOLUTE GRADING

Final Exam 40%

Adequate
5 online quizzes
1 concert report

reviews.author: ychb
reviews.title: Probably the easiest music course in HKUST
reviews.comment_content: Music history from Medieval to the 20th century. Some very basic music knowledge. You need not to know much about music since it is a course for everyone, including those without musical background
reviews.comment_teaching: Somewhere between fine and boring, I think it is a result of listening to a lot of stuff from Tommasini reading from the ppt. It can be quite sleepy if you are taking the afternoon session.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading, A- in the end. A good grade course for people who likes to memorize stuff. Even better if you have some musical background.

My results:
Quiz 1: 37/40
Quiz 2: 38/40
Quiz 3: 39/40
Quiz 4: 40/40
Quiz 5: 40/40
Concert report: 13/15
Midterm: 72/86
Final: 128/140
Overall: 90.2/100 (Grade: A-)
reviews.comment_workload:
Fine, only 5 online quiz in canvas, a concert report, 1 midterm and final. More about the syllabus could be referred to the attachment, the professor would mention more about the assignments and exams

Remember to attend all lectures since attendance contributes to one tenth towards your final grade. The attendance are taken with the iPRS.

You could find most of the answers of the online quiz from the lecture notes, or you can copy the question and search it on google. Try to find a website called quizlet on google. In case the question bank of the quiz has no changes, quizlet should have half of the answers for all the online quiz (so sad that I didn't find this out until the 3rd online quiz).

For the concert report, try to find some famous musical pieces as the main subject to be discussed in the paper. Since it is much easier to gather more information on internet or some other people's research. Tommasini would help you on your thesis statement. You don't need to worry much that you need to write sth really technical.

For the exams, revise more on the lecture notes and don't miss out any details. Try to listen the mentioned music through the course more, able to recognize the musical pieces immediately is very helpful to the exams. About the listening part, the midterm focuses on stuff from Medieval Period to Classical Period, while the finals focuses on Romantic Period to 20th Century.

reviews.author: SmallShortGuy
reviews.comment_content:
It is quite meaningless to memorize the place of birth of composers...
but overall it is about music history and change of composition methods instead of theory
Interesting only if you are THAT interested in music history
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is really passionate and he expects his students to be passionate and (absolutely) quiet as well.
To be honest he teaches really well.  He explains music history very clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance 10% (pick 10 lectures to take)
Online quizzes 10% (super high mean, almost full)
Concert report 15%
Midterm 25% (listening, mc)
Final 40% (listening, mc)

Super harsh absolute grading
9X% --> A range
8X% --> B range
sth like this

I have good memory so I thought I could have good result
I really memorized a lot
But it turned out that I could not realize which song it was playing in exams so I couldn't answer the questions at all
reviews.comment_workload:
Only 1 assignment which is the concert report
The greatest problem is simply whether you can easily realize which song it is from the recording (friendly reminder the songs are really similar to each other and the lyrics of especially operas are NOT IN ENGLISH goshhhhhh)

reviews.author: Yauuuuu
reviews.comment_content: Introducing classical music from the middle age to the 20th Century. If you are a classical music lover, you would definitely find this course interesting telling the details of the development and the story behind those famous masterpieces. If you are not, good luck with your brain.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching was great and detailed. He followed the notes most of the time and played us some melody using the piano in class. The course provides lecture video so we can review when we missed some music terms on the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading, kind of horrible that it would be definitely an F if you are getting lower than 60%. I got all quizzes full marks and around 60-70% for the exams and got a D TT
reviews.comment_workload: Quite low workload that there is no daily assessment or long essay to do. There are five online quizzes which have time limitation. And you are also required to submit a hard copy of a concert report at the end of the semester, which required you to go to some related classical music concerts yourself and write the report according to that experience.

reviews.author: Yau
reviews.title: Role learning in the end (enjoyment??) instructor change in next term
reviews.comment_content:
The course covered music from dark age to 20 century music. At first the songs are quite easy to rmb. However the content gets more complicated after midterm. Some of the songs are quite weird to me. I am quite interest in classical music, but remembering all The names, home countries, history, year of the piece of over 30 songs drive me CRAZY.

Heres the playlist of FINAL exam.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLmLx8Swhzj8zKy9LBnxHibup2bLPdFUNl
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. will start the lecture by reviewing what he hv said last time. At first there are some interactions in class like sing tgt. At the end of the term, sometime he just read out the ppt. he spend so much time to explain thesis statement which is quite boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading components:
Final Exam 40%
Mid-Term Exam 25%
Concert Report 15%
Online Quizzes 10%
Attendance 10%

EXAM: the exams is all in mc q. First part of the exam is general questions, and the second part of the exam contains listening part. Fragments of different songs will be played and you have to answer 5 questions about each song.

CONCERT REPORT: student have to attend concert in order to finish the concert report. I think it is hard for student without music background to describe those piece.

QUIZ: online quiz are open book, just search keywords from the ppt and you can easily get full mark.

ATTENDANCE: random ,IPRS

Grading is on an absolute basis, not easy to get good grade but hard to get D or F.
reviews.comment_workload: This course is good for those student who good at mesmerizing. It is not enjoyable anymore at the end of the course. Having midterm, final, essay, quizzes, attendance, I don't think it worth 3 credits because you have to spend so much time but may not get a good grade as a result.

reviews.author: sd1214
reviews.comment_content:
Medieval Music
Renaissance Music
Baroque Music
Classical Period Music
Romantic Music
Contemporary Art Music (Twentieth Century Music)

Not musically difficult, but pretty heavy content because there's a lot to memorize. It gets pretty interesting during Classical Period and Romantic music because you will notice some of the well-known musicians and musical pieces. Contemporary Art music is the most difficult part since you will barely recognize any of them.
Overall, very organised content and well structured ppt. A lot of names and terms to memorize and the most difficult part is to remember the musical piece itself sounds like as they give music questions in exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tommasini is a great professor. He is funny and passionate in teaching; despite the heavy content, he does not keep the lectures boring by playing pianos and making us sing during the lectures at times. He also reviews thesis statement for your concert reports if you email him in advance.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
B+ 88 â€“ 89.99%
B 82 â€“ 87.99%
B- 80 â€“ 81.99%
C+ 78 â€“ 79.99%
C 72 â€“ 77.99%
C- 70 â€“ 71.99%
D 60 â€“ 69.99%
F 0 â€“ 59.99%

Final Exam: 40%
Mid-Term Exam: 25%
Concert Report: 15%
Online Quizzes: 10%
Attendance: 10%

It looks pretty tough just looking at the absolute grading system, but the grade weighting is pretty well distributed. As long as you attend the lectures and concerts, you get easy 10% for attendance. Online quizzes are open-book, so it's easy to get full 10%, and it helps you to practice for your midterm and finals. And as long as you study the contents properly you can get decent scores in the exams. The most tricky one is the concert report. To give some tips, it's really important to formulate a good thesis statement, which you can ask the professor to review it for you. In addition, use a lot of musical vocabularies learnt to aim for higher scores.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light workload excluding the heavy content that you need to memorize for the exams. Lecture videos are uploaded, although there is randomly taken attendance. Only one assignment, which is the concert report. In order to complete this, you have to attend the open discussions and 2 concerts in weekends. You will probably think like "Why am I attending concerts in a university of science and technology?" but it's a pretty fun and enjoyable experience.

reviews.author: jhjhjhjjhjhhhhj
reviews.comment_content:
EXAMS:
There will be one Mid-Term Exam and one Final Exam. The Mid-Term will take place during
regularly scheduled lecture time. The Final Exam time and place will be announced later in
the semester. No make-up exams will be offered, unless an excused absence form is
submitted on time with the proper justification.
ONLINE QUIZZES:
Five (5) Quizzes will be administered via CANVAS over the course of the semester to allow
students the opportunity to evaluate their progress in the course and prepare for the Mid-Term
and Final Exams. Quiz scores WILL COUNT towards the final grade in the course as outlined
below. Online Quizz 1 will be administered with NO TIME LIMIT during the 24-hour period.
Online Quizzes 2-5 will have a TIME LIMIT OF 2 HOURS during the 24-hour period. No
make-ups will be offered.
INTIMACY OF CREATIVITY REPORT:
Students will be required to attend events of the Intimacy of Creativity 2018 (IC2018), the
internationally-acclaimed composers and performers initiative presented by HKUST, and write
a paper describing their experiences (500-600 words).
Students are required to attend 2 Open Discussions or Lunchtime Lectures and 1 concert
event per week of events (6 sessions total). Most of these sessions will not take place during regularly-scheduled lecture times. An online registration form with complete details will be circulated later in the semester, along with further details on alternate arrangements or
exemptions. Students are required to attend 6 sessions total. All sessions will be
presented in-lieu of regular lecture sessions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tommasini is a good instructor who makes his point clear and easy for student to understand
reviews.comment_grading: ABSOLUTE GRADING
reviews.comment_workload: A bit heavy workload for common core course. In order to get A-range in this course, you need to perform well on both exams and online quizzes.

reviews.author: CrystalZheng
reviews.comment_content:
It teaches the history of classical music. Starts from very beginning, talking about where is music from and start. (Which is quite boring at the beginning). Then it will go through the Baroque, Classical, Romantic and 20th-century music, introducing the representative pieces and composers at that period.

Some basic music theories will also be taught.
reviews.comment_teaching: There will be a lot of listening and analyzing during the class. The professor is not an interesting professor, but he is knowledgeable
reviews.comment_grading: If you are interested in the classical music and music theory, the grading would be ok.
reviews.comment_workload:
- Midterm exam
- Final exam
- Short online quiz weekly
- Concert report

reviews.author: Marvinhtr
reviews.comment_content: This course teaches about classical music throughout the ages with their special characteristics for each age and how they evolve. The ages are the Middle Ages, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, and 20th century. Whether the material will be interesting or not depends on your interest in art, classical music, or history. You don't need to have musical background to learn in this course, but it will be much easier and less tedious if you do.
reviews.comment_teaching: The Professor teaches in very fluent English. He talks clearly and not too quickly. In the beginning, he actively encourages student participation, but by the end, he mostly only asks the students during the practice for the tests.
reviews.comment_grading: 25% for midterms, 40% for finals, 10% for quizzes, 15% for concert report, and 10% for attendance. The quizzes are basically free score since you're allowed ample time to look at the notes. The main problem with this course's scoring is its absolute grade system. To get A+, you need to obtain at least 98% score. For A, it's 92-98%. The grading very harsh and since it's absolute, you can't rely on low average to help you out.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. You need to do 5 quizzes. The first two are given 24 hours to complete while the rest are given 2 hours. It's more than enough to try to complete it without looking and then checking back with the notes. The concert report might be harder, but it's only 600 words and you'll get a high score for it if you know how to use the musical terms taught in the course.

reviews.author: wcywongcy
reviews.comment_content: It is about the history of music. Only some techniques will be covered in the course. Also, it focuses on the composer that you need to memorise quite some background of them.
reviews.comment_teaching: It's good if you enjoy listening to classical music and like the history of music. Otherwise, you may be bored.
reviews.comment_grading: It is quite hard to get a very good grade as the absolute grading scale is quite high.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 5 online quizzes, one final midterm and one final exam.
Also, you need to go for 6 concerts and discussion, and finishing one concert report in spring sem course.

reviews.author: DHJang
reviews.comment_content:
Mid-term, Final, Online quiz, mandatory concert participation, class participation grade, one-page concert report for this course.

General go-through of western classical music all the way from the medieval music to contemporary music.

Throughout the course, the professor introduces literally TONS of musical pieces along with the historical background and details about the composers (name, the year he or she was born, birth country etc..). You don't have to have musical background or anything, but it would make the lecture sound more familiar if you have some.

The overall content of the lecture was okay for me in terms of the variety of music and music-related knowledge that I did not know before. However, I am not sure if I enjoyed listening to those, especially when I was preparing for the exams since as exam periods approach, the amount of stuff that you have to memorize pile up and eventually become a burden. (at least for me)

Hence, I suggest you actually go over the lecture notes and actually listen the pieces again and familiarize yourself to the content. That way, you won't have to stay up all night the day before the exam to scram all the content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He has this grand piano in front of the lecture theater and play some notes or lines from the pieces that he introduces, and this, for me, was nice.

The professor sounded passionate and I could really see how much he wants to introduce these pieces to students. However, the overall lecture style is kinda dull, so I felt a bit boring during the class.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading. Depends on how much you memorize for the exam. The average and SDs don't mean anything; as long as you memorize all the stuff right, you will be fine. The questions are not hard.. It would feel like you are given a memory test when you face the exam paper.
reviews.comment_workload: Not too much if you continuously review the lecture notes and pieces. A lot if you try to go over the whole material over one night before tests. (not if you are good at memorizing)

reviews.author: d
reviews.comment_content:
Study of music history and some basic music theories

People can get good grade even without musical background
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is really nice and the lessons are interesting

The atmosphere in the lecture is good

He will do some exercises with us which are related to the midterm/exam in class

There are some thesis statement( for the report) given in the lessons as demonstration and you will know the standard of how to write a good concert report.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading course

reviews.title: Enjoyment????
reviews.comment_content:
As mentioned by all previous review.
The content seems unchanged comparing with the previous semesters and this semester.
Before mid-term you will study music from medieval period to classical period.
And after mid-term you will study something from romantic period to 20th century.
