reviews.comment_teaching:
I don't know how to say if his teaching is good or not.
Just try by youeself.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very tough.

What make this course horrible is that you have to remember all the songs that have been taught in that period and the listening part occupy nearly half of the questions of both exams.

For example, in my mid-term there is 100 questions and 40 of them are the listening. You have to listen to 10 clips and answer those questions.
And in the final there is 150 questions and you have 80 listening questions, which means that you have to listening and recognise 16 songs.

My point of view (You can of coz disagree and just ignore, just for reference)
I don't think this is something so-called "enjoyment of music".
This course should be named as "Remembering music".
Even if you work hard and study those characteristics of those periods, you can get a D grade. Yes a D grade. That's what I got as I find it quiet hard to remember all the music, some of them are 1h long and they just take out 1 min of that song and ask you what is that song. Where did the composer born?
If you are confident and you think you have time to remember all those songs, you are of course welcome to take this course.
Otherwise, think twice before taking this "Remembering of Music".

And one more thing: Just pray for that they will not put the final exam of this course with another course together. I had my PHYS1114 final and HUMA1102 final in just one day, exam by exam!!And both of them need hard-work.
reviews.comment_workload:

In the end of the semester a concert report.
Workload is not something making this course tough.

reviews.author: Stanni Darwin
reviews.comment_content:
This course talks about the 4 periods in classical music which are Baroque, Classical, Romantic, and Twentieth Century periods. The professor will start with music from the Dark Ages first, and it's better if you understand that since he'll use this period for references in the future.

He'll talk about the composers, how an excerpt of a piece of classical music differs from or resonates with another, and how to spot the differences so we can know what piece is from which period. The professor will repeat those three anyways, so if you attend the lectures and really listen then you'll be able to get it.

He posts lecture videos, too, so if you were absent from a class you could just go on Canvas and then watch the video from there, although he sometimes uses iPRS to take attendance without prior notice so you have to be on the lookout for that.
reviews.comment_teaching: He's easy to understand, comprehensive, and doesn't stray away from the bullet points in his ppt files. Even if you don't listen to his lectures, you can still study from ppt files so there's no way you'll flunk this course.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading's absolute, but the quizzes were easy and if you really go through the ppt files and memorise the songs he talked about in his lectures, Midterm and Final are gonna be easy as well.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload was pretty light since he gave 1 online quiz after 3 or 4 lectures. All the quizzes consisted of 40 MCQ and were timed, except for the first two. Some of the quizzes' questions were also included in Midterm's and Final's exams, and the good thing is that we can still review the quizzes even after we submitted them.

Also, we were required to attend a classical concert and submit a 500 to 600-word report about it alongside the ticket stub. I think if you already have basics in classical music, it'll be easier for you to write the report but you can still go through all his lecture files and then incorporate those music-related phrases into your report.

reviews.comment_grading: Most students who apply this course are dedicated to memorizing. So the more hardworking you are, the greater the grading you will get
reviews.comment_workload: You better be prepared to memorize many musical terms and characteristics of different musical period. Sometimes there are online quiz. In the last lesson, you have to hand in an essay reviewing a play/ drama.

reviews.comment_content: The lecture covers practically everything from the beginning of Western classical music to the 20th century. Some things like Dies Irae keeps popping up between the centuries, which is understandable given the universal usage of the motif throughout the centuries. The music may not be to everyone's tastes but they were adequate representations of the important themes in those time periods.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Tommasini is a very spirited instructor, who is also very knowledgeable and prepared for all his lectures. He also does his own compositions which were nice to hear during one of the concerts. One of the better professors at UST.

reviews.author: aal
reviews.title: Interesting and engaging
reviews.comment_content: As a fan of classical music, I found this class extremely interesting and informative. Tommasini went through the history of music from gregorian chants to contemporary music, and taught concepts by presenting songs for each period. I enjoyed that he explained the history of famous composers as well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Tommasini is a fantastic professor who is obviously very passionate about classical music. I found him extremely engaging and enjoyed hearing him explain musical concepts and history.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was very fair. Tommasini assigned five online quizzes throughout the semester (which were open note and very easy to do well on) that allowed you to understand what types of questions would be on his midterm/final. I appreciated that he allowed us to see how he would be asking questions before we took tests.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was fair. Five online quizzes throughout the semester were easy as you could look up the answers in your notes. Midterm and final were as expected, not too difficult if you knew the content. There was also a concert report that required you to attend a concert and write about it, which I found enjoyable.

reviews.author: hungrypotato

reviews.comment_content:
Covers Medieval, Baroque, Classical, Romantic and 21st Century music. Quite intense...... (I heard music majors cover all these periods in 4 years... while we are doing this in one semester... Professor Tommasini is quite ambitious I guess)

I wasn't a huge fan of the Medieval and 21st Century music, so the content was a little boring for me. Professor Tommasini is American, so I guess that explains why he taught so much on American music... (I was wondering where Enjoyment of "Classical Music" went)

The format of content taught goes like this:
1. period
2. special feature A/B/C
3. several music piece as examples to reflect special features A/B/C
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Tommasini prepares class thoroughly and often starts lesson by repeating some content from the previous lesson. As long as you pay attention in class and try to memorise alongside his teaching (and not forget things), the content shouldn't be too difficult to study.

(he always shhhhes people though, which I hated a lot because sometimes I don't even hear people talk but he shhhhes)
reviews.comment_grading:

- 5 online quizzes (open book quiz, quiz 1-2: 24 hours to do; quiz 3-5: 2 hours to do) [10%]
- 1 final exam [40%]
- 1 concert report (500 words) [15%]
- 10 random iPRS [10%]
*****all exams and quizzes are MCs

The midterm exam covered Medieval, Baroque and Classical periods. The final exam is non-cumulative (decided later by the professor) covered Romantic and 21st Century periods.

Concert report was pretty tough. Professor Tommasini showed examples of thesis statements and allowed us to send it to him by email and he gave us advices. Doesn't help with writing the report though...

Quiz was easy, people basically scored full mark.

I attended all iPRS, got almost full marks for all of my quizzes, got 96/100 for midterm, 137/150 for finals and 13.5/15 for concert report. Finally got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: Not that much, as there were only 5 quizzes evenly distributed throughout the whole semester. The concert report was tough, but as long as you don't be a deadline fighter and listen to a concert that is very close to the deadline, 500 words shouldn't be too hard to cram.

reviews.author: TF
reviews.title: Musical background and understanding are really decisive
reviews.comment_content:
The lectures cover almost the entire historical development of western music. The instructor begins with Middle Age music, followed by Medieval and Renaissance music. These musical eras only cover a small part of the syllabus. The main focus is on the common-practice period, which means the Baroque, Classical and Romantic periods. 20th Century music also possesses a significant part but the instructor may not go in depth.

The lecture slides introduce the history and culture of different musical periods and explain the characteristics of the compositions in the corresponding eras. A few examples of composers and their works will then be cited.

Some musical theories, such as circle of fifths are included as well. Students have to be familiar with the manipulation of musical keys such as parallel and relative major/minor and dominant keys.

The exams are likely to be precise and goes into details like the composers' nationality and the definition of musical terms.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lecture slides are very lucid, with a clear flow of ideas and explanations. However, there are still some questions on the slides that are answered neither on the slides or in the lectures. Another problem is the repetition of content. The instructor copies the slides that he has not covered onto the next slide. But overall the presentation is quite comprehensible.

The instructor emphasizes a lot on the concert report and he sometimes spend 1/3 of the lecture to talk about the details. However, the way he delivers the messages is outstanding. It will not be very hard for students without musical background to understand. His enthusiasm and attitude towards music is conspicuous.

Students must attend the Intimacy of Creativity Concerts as well as the discussion sessions but not everyone finds it interesting. Some of the students may not be able to appreciate the artistry and assimilate the communication between the musicians. The atmosphere of the discussion sessions is a bit awkward.

Concert Report (500-600 words): 15%
Online Quizzes (5 in total): 10%
Attendance (randomly taken in lectures+concert discussion sessions+attendance of the concert): 10%


Quite demanding grading system as a whole.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload of the students for the exams really depends on the musical background and understanding of the students. For students who did not listen much classical music, it could be challenging and disadvantageous to memorize the melodies and features of tens or even hundreds of musical pieces with different genres, plus the details mentioned during lectures. The exams consist of tons of questions about every detail covered in the syllabus and it requires much effort and time to study for a good grade.

The online quizzes are open-book tests so most of the students get very high percentages.

The grading of the concert report is quite ambiguous and opaque. A seriously done work does not guarantee a satisfactory mark.

The workload is high compared to other common core courses.

reviews.author: supersherlockxd
reviews.title: No relationship between "enjoyment" and the course (except the course title, maybe)?
reviews.comment_content:
background: music team in one of the best schools in terms of music in Hong Kong, USTUC ex-member

i still find the course too chur, since it covers from middle ages to contemporary music. the prof expects you to have some music knowledge (although not explicitly said so).
reviews.comment_teaching: the prof is passionate about music, that's for certain, but sometimes he can deliver in quite a boring way, in the sense that he expects everyone to know as much music history and theory as he does.
reviews.comment_grading:
absolutely rubbish!

you can get A range only for 90% or above. unless you have no course to take other than huma 1102, and you have superb memory, AND somehow you managed to memorise all the songs' melodies and names, it's impossible to get to A range.

results: C
reviews.comment_workload: so so, MT final attendance and concert report (because i study in fall sem, spring sem is more chur). The exams are hard as hell even studying the practice questions

reviews.author: rei
reviews.title: Good Course if u are hard working enough
reviews.comment_content:
very interesting, including from ancient time to 20th century
very suitable to those who are obsessed with music
reviews.comment_teaching:
the professor try to make the atmosphere more relaxing
but he only say the powerpoint stuff out
reviews.comment_grading:
absolute grading
not many assignments
have a few quizzes but open book, so it is very easy to get high score and getting A range
there are midterm and final but if u can memorize all the things it is not difficult to get A
including taking iPRS for 10 times, so it is better to attend the lesson
reviews.comment_workload:
only 1 concert report in fall sem
suggested that enroll this subject in fall sem but not spring sem
there are few quizzes but very easy
not many assignment so workload is very light

reviews.author: Monkey
reviews.comment_content:
The materials taught in this course is very informative.
History and basic musical knowledge are taught.   
Suitable for both types of students with or without a musical background.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof is passionate about music and has a nice accent.
I find his teaching very interesting but some might find it boring if they are not interested in music.
reviews.comment_grading: Midterm and finals are all MCs question, covers literally every corner of the lecture slides so study everything (year and place of birth of composers) and memorize all the songs listed and you will be fine.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only a concert report should be handed in at the end of the semester, plus online quizzes (get marks as long as you finished the quiz)
*questions in the quizzes is similar or even the same to questions appeared in exams.

reviews.author: devina
reviews.comment_content: It is better if you have a background in music, but it is okay if you don't have a background in music.
reviews.comment_teaching: If you are interested in music, you might like this course. The lecture is pretty clear and pretty interesting. You can access lecture video on canvas. The TA will provide youtube playlist before midterm and final.
reviews.comment_grading: This is an absolute grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 5 online quizzes (self test). The exam questions are pretty similar with the quizzes.
You have to attend 2 big concert and 4 mini concert (Intimacy of Creativity) in Spring and you have to make a 500 words report based on the concert. It is better to take this course in Fall as you should only attend 1 concert.

reviews.author: _ry
reviews.comment_content:
The course is about classical music from medieval, renaissance, baroque, classical, romantic period to the twentieth century.
For each musical period, 5-10 songs will be introduced as examples, and these songs are exactly the content for exams.
For each song, it is suggested to memorize the background, specific technique adopted and, most importantly, the composer and where the composer was born.
Songs will be played in lectures while prof will explain and elaborate a bit on it. On powerpoint slides, there are links of the songs.
Besides that, some musical terms will be taught, like texture: polyphonic and monophonic.
Attendance will be taken for 10 times randomly through iprs. Sometimes attendance may be taken at the end of class, it may NOT always be taken at the beginning.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof was really nice, he answered questions clearly on classes.
He taught a bit fast, he always went through the slides quickly.
But he always gave us exam reviews before midterm and final exam and sometimes questions on reviews would appear on exam paper. So, reviews are really important.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course uses absolute grading system:
A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
B+ 88 â€“ 89.99%
B 82 â€“ 87.99%
B- 80 â€“ 81.99%
C+ 78 â€“ 79.99%
C 72 â€“ 77.99%
C- 70 â€“ 71.99%
D 60 â€“ 69.99%
F 0 â€“ 59.99%

Personally, I think it is quite harsh.
I put a lot of effort and time on this course, memorizing the songs was a complete nightmare, matching them with their composer was even worse. Eventually, even though I got an A-, I would say this course was hard.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light.
IC report is the only assignment of this course and you should only write for 500-600 words.
Online quizzes are open-book and usually they take you less than 1 hour. Everything can be found on the slides, or else you only need to google it.
Attendance will be taken for 10 times randomly through iprs, in order words, 1% for each attendance.

Final Exam 40%
Mid-Term Exam 25%
IC2016 Report 15%
Online Quizzes 10%
Attendance 10%

reviews.author: minna_
reviews.comment_content:
The course introduces classical music from medieval, renaissance, baroque, classical, romantic period to the twentieth century. Professor will talk about different pieces for each period, in which around 4-5 pieces will be discussed for medieval and renaissance, and around 10-15 pieces will be discussed for the rest of the periods. For each piece, the professor will briefly talk about the author and the techniques used.
I found the content quite interesting as I knew more about different styles of music. There are many good pieces that I can still remember now.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor tries very hard to engage the whole class by sometimes asking us to sing along and tap the beat of different pieces. He always asks if we have questions and answers to students' enquiries sincerely.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course uses absolute grading, while some people find it a bad way as the benchmark is too high, I think it can motivate myself to do better and achieve a better grade.
Below is the grading system:

A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
B+ 88 â€“ 89.99%
B 82 â€“ 87.99%
B- 80 â€“ 81.99%
C+ 78 â€“ 79.99%
C 72 â€“ 77.99%
C- 70 â€“ 71.99%
D 60 â€“ 69.99%
F 0 â€“ 59.99%
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light.
- Final exam is not cumulative. To study for mid-term and final exam, I think the best way is to memorise everything (the music and the notes), and I have to admit that students with musical background will do better in this course.
- 1 concert report is also required. The concert report will be written after attending the Intimacy of Creativity. When I was taking the course (spring 2017), I had to attend 2 festivals (Contemporary Song and Instrumental Chamber Music Festival), each consists of 2 discussion platforms and 1 concert.
- There are 5 online quizzes to complete during the course, but they are all open book.
- Attendance will be taken for IC events,10 random attendance-taking will also be carried out during lectures throughout the course.
Below is the workload distribution:

Final Exam 40%
Mid-Term Exam 25%
IC2017 Report 15%
Online Quizzes 10%
Attendance 10%

reviews.author: PotterSiu
reviews.title: Easy course but you have to memorize hard for good garde
reviews.comment_content:
Introducing type of classical music during different period
Some songs, their background, relevant musicians, music techniques and so on
Basically, most of the lecture material are simple to understand by only reading the lecture notes. (Lecture video are also provided)
But, some of the music concepts are hard for those having no music background to learn. Actually, they are most likely not to include in the test and exam.

Overall, it is interesting
reviews.comment_teaching:
Not bad, try to provide the best education in the lesson.
The professor plays several music and play the piano in every lesson, sometimes students may need to sing together. Haha
He like repeats the content of last lecture for students to review.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute garding
>60% D
>70% C range
>80% B range
>90% A range

15% music report
10% attendance
10% self test (canvas online test, open-book)
25% midterm
40% final

Quite fair, the garde depends on how much time you pay in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
In spring, you are required to attend several music concerts and related activities. Then you need to submit the music report about those events by applying the concepts you study in the course in the last lecture. Not very difficult, not worried.
The most of the time you spend in this course may be memorizing the lecture notes and listening the songs in YouTube.
Workload actually is not heavy.

reviews.author: Kelvinsuennnn
reviews.comment_content: This course covers a wild range of  music pieces from medieval to 20th century. Students will learn about basic musical terms and expressions, as well as backgrounds of composers.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor emphasizes main point and repeats important terminology and content so you will know what to study. You can enjoy listening good music during the lesson as he play through them.
reviews.comment_grading: Easy to get good grade. You just have to memorize the notes and power point, matching composers and the music piece with the techniques used in it. You will get good score easily on quizes.
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly no assignment. You just have to finish a few quizzes, as well as an essay before the end of semester.

reviews.author: mkb
reviews.comment_content: For those who have no musical background, you need not feel worried. Assessment in this course EMPHASISES ON MEMORY BUT NOT YOUR MUSICAL CAPABILITY to answer the questions. For example, in the general question part, they ask you what form is Beethoven Sonata No.2 movement 2 in, without playing the excerpt. And for instance, in the listening question part, by just playing you a short clip, they would ask you the plot, characters' name and why they feel sad.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think this professor is able to convey musical knowledge to ones with no musical background. Also, if you miss his lesson, you can view the recorded lesson in canvas.
reviews.comment_grading:
Since this course is absolute grading, you can predict your own grade.
5quizzes, 1 conert report, 1midterm and 1 final contribute to your final grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 5 quizzes throughout out the term. Nevertheless, all of the quizzes are take-home, which means that you can answer the questions after flipping through your notes, searching relevant information on Internet etc.
There are also one midterm and one final, all are mc questions, with both general questions and listening questions.

reviews.author: peggygg
reviews.comment_content:
Music from Medieval time to the 20th century.
Background of each piece and the composer.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is nice and he provided a lot of materials for mid-term and final.
In every lesson, he repeated a few of content from last lesson in order to refresh our memory.
reviews.comment_grading: Not really very good. There is an absolute grading system. You can get at least B if you work hard. However, A is extremely difficult to get.
reviews.comment_workload: Just a few online quizzes and a concert report. You can do it at the last minute.

reviews.author: KW
reviews.comment_content: this class will briefly talk about classical music from the dark age to 21st century. it is not really difficult but there are a lot to memorize.
reviews.comment_teaching: the prof did a really good job delivering the content. he would show you lots of music clips which you need to memorize for the midterm and final.
reviews.comment_grading:
25 % midterm, 40% final, 10% participation, 10% online quizzes, 15% concert report
absolute grading scale.
the midterm and final are non cumulative. both are pretty easy but you do need to recite the ppt.
reviews.comment_workload: students will be required to attend 1 classical music concert and write a report (600 words)

reviews.author: venska
reviews.comment_content:
Course Overview:
1. Medieval Music
2. Renaissance Music
3. Baroque Music
4. Classical Period Music
5. Romantic Music
6. Twentieth Century Art Music

Materials should be enjoyable if you like music. You will need to memorize song titles and composers for the exams.

There are 5 online quiz (self-tests) in canvas. The questions in the exam will be similar to the questions in the quiz.

There is 1 concert report (500-600 words) due at the end of the course. The professor will go through some examples of thesis statements multiple times in the class.

Attendance is taken 10 times randomly throughout the semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: In my view, Professor Tommasini tries to make memorizing things fun. Sometimes, we are asked to sing a short line of a song or clap to beats so that we remember the song. He also teaches musical concepts (e.g. circle of fifths) repeatedly to make sure that everyone, including those who don't have any music background, understands the materials. He also goes through some thesis statements for the concert report in class to help us get the idea of what he wants in the report.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading:
Final Exam 40%
Mid-Term Exam 25%
Concert Report 15%
Online Quizzes 10%
Attendance 10%

Absolute grading:
A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
B+ 88 â€“ 89.99%
B 82 â€“ 87.99%
B- 80 â€“ 81.99%
C+ 78 â€“ 79.99%
C 72 â€“ 77.99%
C- 70 â€“ 71.99%
D 60 â€“ 69.99%
F 0 â€“ 59.99%
reviews.comment_workload:
Not that much work to do, but try to do your concert report as soon as you finish watching the concert. It will help you remember more from the concert.

Other than the concert report, just remember to finish your self-tests on time (you will be given 24 hours). Both the professor and TA will remind you repeatedly in class and through e-mail/canvas about this.

reviews.author: Josh Siu
reviews.title: True Enjoyment of University
reviews.comment_content:
- History of music from:
Medieval Period (1150-1450), Renaissance Period (1450-1600), Baroque Period(1600-1750),
Classical Period,
Romantic Period (1820-1900) and 20th Century Period Music (1900-2000).

Music Works includes:
- Symphonies,
- Recitative and Aria,
- Opera,
- Piano Sonata,
- Chamber Music
- And many more!!

Composer Includes:
- Bach
- Haydn
- Beethoven
- Mozart
- Mendelssohn
- Chopin
- Berlioz
- Tchaikovsky
- Wagner
- Brahms
- Mahler
- And many more!

- It will introduce different composers and their work of each period and their musical qualities in a very simple way.

- For example, Beethoven symphony No.5 (my favorite), Mozart Clarinet Quintet K. 581 in A major...

- Does not need any previous knowledge in music theory or any thing like that.

- Youtube link of the music included in all the notes:

- Medieval to Classical:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-fMHms5Cvsw&list=PLmLx8Swhzj8ySQ_Grs1zoOoF1SffeFUWI

- Romantic to 20th Century:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dDuvJmY00cY&list=PLMh_uw8j6e5EDNB6QM_qav3K9knOJQpZk
reviews.comment_teaching:
- Systematic, efficient. It follows the course schedule each week.
- Very interactive teaching environment  (We sang Dies Irae together during class)
- Very enthusiastic and professional towards music and teaching
- Previous lecture will be reviewed in the beginning of next lecture so that you can pick up where the class is
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme:
Final Exam 40%
Mid-Term Exam 25%
IC2016 Report 15%
Online Quizzes 10%
Attendance 10%

(Specifics in Workload Section)

The final grade of this course is determined by absolute grading scale:
A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
B+ 88 â€“ 89.99%
B 82 â€“ 87.99%
B- 80 â€“ 81.99%
reviews.comment_workload:
Final Exam 40%
- Romantic Period to 20th Century
- ~200 MCQ, 100 of them is listening examples

Mid-Term Exam 25%
- Medieval Period to Classical Period
- ~100 MCQ (I forgot), Also includes listening examples.

***Only music appeared in the lecture notes will be used in all exams***

IC2016 Report 15%
You are required to attend a music concert and write an essay about it.
- 500-600 words
- Apply the concept in the report(e.g. Sonata-Allegro, Theme and Variation, Circle of Fifths, Major and minor scale,Rhythm, Melody, Harmony and Counterpoint, Timbre, characteristics of each period) in the lecture notes
- Standard academic essay: Thesis Statement, Paragraph one, Paragraph two, Conclusion
- Professor will show many thesis statement example
- No need fancy introduction paragraph
- Submit at the last lecture along with the original program leaflet and ticket stub
- You can attend concert or event hosted by University or any other formal philharmonic and orchestral performance if professor approves it. (Just email him or ask him after class)

Online Quizzes 10%
- Five Canvas Online Quizzes
- 24 Hours Time Limit
- All answers can be easily found in the notes if studied thoroughly
- Submit the answer with great caution, you can only submit ONCE!
- Multiple Listening example using the link provided in the lecture notes or the Youtube link.
- Very good indicator of how well you have study

Attendance 10%
- Attendance will be taken using PRS or iPRS
- Taken randomly 10 times during the semester

Conclusion:
- Review according to the course schedule each week is strongly advised
- Absolute grading scale can make lazy student get C range easily or even D.
- One must not simply go the exam without any review!!!
- Just enjoy the music and the *concept*, *idea* behind each piece of music
- I am now starting to appreciate these type of music
- I am now listening to Beethoven Symphony No.5 and No.7 and Chopin Nocturne Op 27 No.2 and Op 9 No. 2 everyday!
- Dies Irae UST!

reviews.author: kkm
reviews.title: Not suitable for students who have weak music knowledge and skills
reviews.comment_content: The content has covered a wide range of classical music and instruments. For example, romantic period, renaissance, medieval times and modern music period.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching materials are good but too long in personal speaking.
reviews.comment_grading: I think that he used absolute grading in this semester. As I got a straight D when I have nearly 60% in the course.
reviews.comment_workload: You have to finish a few of self-test based on the lectures, a concert report in more than 500 words, a mid-term and final examination. Fair enough but too much for me.

reviews.author: cyg
reviews.comment_content: This course covers famous and representative music pieces from medieval to 20th century.Students will learn about basic musical terms and expressions, as well as backgrounds of composers.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very single direction teaching. The professor emphasizes main point and repeats important terminology and content so you will know what to study.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair Absolute grading. Memorize everything, matching composers and the music piece with the techniques used in it will give you a good mark in the two quizzes.
reviews.comment_workload: Midterm, final exam in MC format and one concert report. There are 5 self-test that you can take your time to finish at home.

reviews.author: Justin9165
reviews.comment_content: The content was very broad, covering from music in the middle ages all the way to modern music and including about 70~80 pieces of music to memorize. Also, each piece of music has 3~10 slides of information to be studied. For those who do not enjoy listening to music or lack genuine interest in classic musics, memorizing all those information for the exams can be tedious for some extent
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor seemed to be very enthusiastic. He tried his best to convey the materials in a effective way.
reviews.comment_grading:
Exams are very straightforward: memorize hard, you get good grades. Exams cover about 65% of total grade, attendance 10%, self test (24hours of time for each quiz, completely open book, so basically a free grade) 10%, attendace 10%, essay 15%.

If you manage to handle well on exams and get about average on the essay, you can get A or A-. (or A+, if you manage to get 98/100 for your final grade)
reviews.comment_workload:
Memorizing test materials for the test almost entirely consists of this course's workload. There are adequate slides of ppt (70~80 slides per week), so memorizing those for the exams seems to be manageable.

Also, if you do not mind losing grades on 10% attendance, you do not need to attend any lectures for the test; just pure memorization will do the job.

reviews.author: scarletblade
reviews.title: Overall good course
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers Music History from:
Middle ages
Renaissance
Classical Period
Romantic Period
20th century

You have to memorize characteristics of music pieces and composers, style and techniques of every period, etc.

Topics are easy to pick up and no worries if you do not have any music background

Around 30-40 songs you need to know for midterm and finals

You need to attend a music concert during the course to write a concert report
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Tommasini is a decent professor, and he explains the content clearly.

He reminds us of important deadlines at beginning of every class

Interesting guy, humourous sometimes, and we can see his love for music

And he makes us sing in class together occasionally lol
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute Grading

I got 90+% on both final and midterms

Attendance and quizzes 100%

But screwed up on concert report (11 out of 15, below mean)

But luckily still got an A in the end

But overall should be good grade as long as you spend time memorizing
reviews.comment_workload:
Light Workload

Final Exam        40%
Mid-Term Exam        25%
Concert Report        15%
Online Quizzes        10%
Attendance        10%

Non-cumalative exams for us this semester

Attendance is taken using PRS randomly over the semester, and it could be at the start, or at the end, or in the middle of class.

Search 'Huma 1102' on youtube and listen to the playlist often to get the tunes into your head as there are listening sections on the exam and you need to recognize the songs.

I spend about 2-3 hours every week on this course just memorizing the ppt lol

reviews.author: legendarychriz
reviews.title: Concert report is the key to get A range
reviews.comment_content:
Talks about classical music, and analyse the composing methods according to different eras.

But, is that really necessary to add 20th century music to this course? especially the electronic music part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Extremely enthusiastic professor in music.
I am also a lover of classical music, so I love his lessons very much.
reviews.comment_grading:
No A range if your final score <90%

Midterm: 88/100 (above mean 0.6 S.D.)  (25%)
Final: 139/150 mean 123.3/150 (92.67%) (40%)
Concert Report: 73.33% (15%)
Quiz: 97% (10%)
Attendance: Attended all lessons so it will be 100% (10%)

For the guy who say Quiz is only counted for participation, fuck you. The Quiz will still count depend on how much answers you get. Please correct it ASAP. Because if Quiz is counted as participation, then I will be over 90% overall. But now I got B+.

Concert report is extremely difficult for me, no idea to analyse the piece of music in an precise way.

If you wish to get A or A+, go through all notes, and pay attention to the scores, because so of the answers will appear on pictures, or corners. I love music so I find nothing difficult when going through the notes.
reviews.comment_workload: It is okay if you love music, but people who watched the course review saying it requires only memorizing, then this course is a torture to them.

reviews.author: Weird Guy
reviews.comment_content: The content covered the development of Classical Music from the Medieval Ages to the 20th Century. It was interesting, even for those without a music background.
reviews.comment_teaching: The Professor speaks excellent English. He tries to make classes very interesting by playing the piano or making the students sing. He uses the concepts from the previous lectures to ease the students into learning new concepts. Overall, very good style of teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is absolute. It is almost impossible to get an A+ in this course as one is required to get a full score in almost everything. Those who can memorise content very well can get an A range in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: There are 5 self-tests for this course. The self-tests are very useful and some of the questions are repeated in the midterm and the final exam. One will have to go for a concert and write a report of 500 words using the concepts covered in class. Also, there is a midterm and final. Those without a music background will have to memorise every detail in this course. The midterm covered 100 MCs in 60 minutes, and the final had 150 MCs in 90 minutes. So, be prepared to answer questions as quickly as possible in the midterm and final exams.

reviews.author: Vicx
reviews.comment_content:
studying music from middle ages all the way to twentieth century.
30 songs for midterm and 50 songs for final.
Playlist available on YouTube.
reviews.comment_teaching:
prof is passionate and presentable
music history rather than theories. Make sure you take some time to memorize every single word on the ppts before exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading. At least 90% for obtaining A range.
A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
Memorize everything on the ppts e.g. the city where the composer was born. Questions are direct though.
reviews.comment_workload: super light workload but the concert report can be though coz have to include concepts and terms mentioned in the lectures.

reviews.author: FiveDemands
reviews.title: Great for those who are music fanatics
reviews.comment_content:
The lectures will cover from the Middle Ages to 20th Century music. For middle, medieval and renaissance periods, the learning materials are relatively less than the Baroque period's and onwards. Remember to listen to the works discussed in the lecture and memorise the characteristics related to these works. The lecture notes will be released before each lecture.
PRS for taking attendance will be done in 10 of all lecture throughout the semester randomly. Bear in mind that sometimes PRS will be taken at the end of the lecture so for those who leave the lecture early will lose some marks in attendance.
The most tricky thing for this course is the concert report which should be handed in in the last lecture. You have to write a report after attending a concert and use musical theories taught in the lecture to appreciate the concert.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has a great passion in music and teaches well. Listening to classical music pieces in-class is an relaxation, especially the professor sometimes performs part of the work by his own.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Exam        40%
Mid-Term Exam        25%
IC2016 Report        15%
Online Quizzes        10%
Attendance        10%

Absolute grading scale:
A+ 98 â€“ 100%
A 92 â€“ 97.99%
A- 90 â€“ 91.99%
B+ 88 â€“ 89.99%
B 82 â€“ 87.99%
B- 80 â€“ 81.99%
C+ 78 â€“ 79.99%
C 72 â€“ 77.99%
C- 70 â€“ 71.99%
D 60 â€“ 69.99%
F 0 â€“ 59.99%
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light.
5 self-tests throughout the semester that are done on Canvas. Getting full mark for self-tests is easy as 24 hours are provided for each test and number of trials is unlimited before submission. If you don't know how to answer self-test questions, just find out answers from the notes within the 24-hour time interval. Before the self-tests, midterm and final, review questions will be released on Canvas and some of self-test questions will appear in midterm and final which are all MCQ.
I think the concert report will consume most time since you have to attend a professional musician's concert and write a report around 500-600 words and you have to write it using musical theories taught in the lectures.

reviews.author: Lawrencceee
reviews.title: Recite and you will got a good grade
reviews.comment_content: If you are interested in music history, this course will be good to you.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching of professor is not too fast, easy to catch up.  But it would be great if you understand a little bit of music, e.g. what is forte, allegro.
reviews.comment_grading: If you spend time to recite all the names and songs, believe me, you won't get a bad grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Sometimes just need to do the self test, and there's a concert report to be completed.  Not very heavy at all. There are some free concert that can be attended in ust, so don't need to worry about the tickets.

reviews.author: ashley___
reviews.comment_content: The pieces taught in class are nice (except those from the 20th century). A few pieces are taught in one lesson.  Music theory stuff are not difficult. Only basic music knowledge will be taught.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lessons are interesting. Professor will play some pieces and ask the class to sing.

TA is nice and helpful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not so good.
Some people with excellent music background will get almost full mark in the exams so the mean will be quite high.

Mid-term: Mean
Final: should be Mean (no idea with the actual score)
Attendance: Attend all the lessons
Self test: Finish all tests
Concert report: No idea with the grade

Got C+ finally
reviews.comment_workload: The only assignment for this course is the concert report which should be handed in at the end of semester. No other assignment but some online-quizzes for revision. Questions in the quizzes will appear again in the mid-term and final.

reviews.author: Sherryl
reviews.title: From the power and beauty of the orchestra to masterpieces of the church and concert hall, students will gain an in-depth appreciation for the history and fundamentals of Western classical music. The listening and analytical skills demonstrated will bring about a deeper understanding of music as an art form. Previous musical training, albeit helpful, is not required.
reviews.comment_content: Development of classical music from medieval to modern ages. Thorough explanations about the composers, characteristics of the piece, and a very little music theory.
reviews.comment_teaching: He explains really clearly about the contents, native english speaker, communicative, very descent overall.
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading so if you completely memorize the whole content you should get A range but it's hard almost impossible to get A+ as you should get full mark on each grading aspects ( mid, final, report, attendance, self-tests)
reviews.comment_workload: Just do self-tests almost every week and there is 500 words long concert report, but the self tests really help for the mid and finals.

reviews.author: wwpy
reviews.title: A lot of stuff to memorize, and the mean is unexpectedly high x_x
reviews.comment_content: The content is very intense and music from the Middle Ages up to the 21th Century and Post-modernism will be taught. Do not expect to learn any practical skills from this course, this course is only designed for students to understand more about the history and development of music. As for the midterm and final exams, there is a substantial amount of materials you need to memorize, including the melodies and characteristics of every piece of music mentioned in the ppt, as there will be MANY questions in the exams where you will listen to part of a song and be able to pinpoint the composer, period, genre, composition technique, and the name of the larger piece it originated from.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is a very serious person, and often repeats announcements he thinks are important. Not much to say about his teaching because he just reads from the ppt and plays videos.
reviews.comment_grading: Despite the massive amount of information to memorize, the mean of this course is pretty high. Scoring below 70% will immediately render you down to C range, and a few of my friends got D.
reviews.comment_workload: There is a short concert report you have to write and hand in two weeks before all the finals start to kick in. There is no required topic for the report so you can come up with whatever thesis statement you like, but the concert must be about classical music. Aside from this, there is not much you need to do for this course, but be sure to revise early for the final as there is really A LOT of music and content you have to memorize.

reviews.author: YESH
reviews.title: HUMA1102
reviews.comment_content:
The whole course consists
1.INTRODUCTION/MEDIEVAL MUSIC
A discussion of Medieval culture, sacred music (including the Medieval mass and motet), and secular forms will cover the work of composers Hildegard of Bingen, Leonin, Perotin, and Machaut.

Music theory concepts related to these works will include fundamentals of rhythm, meter, and melody.

2. RENAISSANCE MUSIC

A discussion of Renaissance culture, vocal music (including the Renaissance mass and motet, and madrigal), and instrumental music will include works by composers Josquin Des Prez and Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina.

Music theory concepts will continue with a brief discussion of elementary contrapuntal techniques.

3. BAROQUE MUSIC

An in-depth analysis of the musical genres from the Baroque period will cover the work of composers Bach, Handel, Purcell, Pachelbel, Corelli, and others.  The section will begin with a discussion of the art, culture, and general philosophy of music during this time period followed by a discussion of vocal genres (oratorio, cantata, and opera) and instrumental genres (the suite, and sonata).



Related music theory concepts will include an introduction to key signatures, major and minor scales, and the circle of fifths.  This will also include a short discussion of the elements of the fugue, and compositional devices like the sequence.


4. CLASSICAL PERIOD MUSIC

This section will cover the works of Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven, focusing on the

development of vocal genres (including opera) and instrumental genres (including the sonata).

In addition, new genres of the concerto and symphony will be covered.



5. ROMANTIC MUSIC

The most extensive section of the semester will begin with a discussion of the chamber music

of early eighteenth century composers Schubert, Mendelssohn, Chopin, and Liszt.

The section will continue with an overview of the continuing development of opera, including

the work of Verdi, Puccini, and Wagner and cover new genres of ballet and program music

with the works of composers Berlioz, Strauss, and Tchaikovsky.



Music from the second half of the eighteenth century will include works by late Romantic

composers Brahms and Tchaikovsky, and nationalist works by Tchaikovsky, Mussorgsky,

Smetana, and others.



The development of harmony and form during this period will be covered as it relates to the

works discussed.





6. TWENTIETH CENTURY ART MUSIC

Lectures will cover the many styles of art music during the twentieth century, beginning with works by early twentieth century composers Debussy, Ravel, Rachmaninoff, Stravinsky, Bartok, Schoenberg, and others.  Impressionism, neo-Romanticism, expressionism, and primitivism will be examined along with neoclassicism and 12-tone music.

The section will continue with works by composers of second half of the twentieth century,

including VarÃ¨se, Crumb, Cage, Copland, and others.



A short discussion of the radical development of theoretical concepts will focus on rhythm

(including ostinato complex, polyrhythm), harmony (including polytonality), and serialism as

they relate to the works during this period
reviews.comment_teaching: The first 15 minutes is promoting the concerts going to hold. Professors would play the piano sometimes. But basically reading for the powerpoints. Skipping all lessons would be fine as long as you ask your friends to take attendance for you.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Self Test ( only account for participation)
10% Attendance
15% Concert Report
25% Midterm
40% Final

Above 0.5 SD -> B
Mean -> B-
Below mean 0.X% -> C+

There is a separate grading for L1 and L2
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload.
Participate in the self test will guarantee 10% of total grade.
Sending your thesis statement to the professor before submission of the concert report would be better. The report is quite easy to write.

reviews.author: LuLu
reviews.title: Good Course
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting course content
+ Just have to memorize everything on the slides and prof's comment.
Exams are quite tricky (and mean was usually high).
Do not miss quiz + review quiz (some quiz questions came out in midterm/final exam)
reviews.comment_teaching: Good prof, very passionate about teaching classical music (sometimes play piano during the class)
reviews.comment_grading: I think generally good grading, most people I know got A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload (except quiz), but need to submit report after watching classical music related concert + also need to do quiz on a regular basis

reviews.author: Spaceship
reviews.title: one MC=one subgrade???
reviews.comment_content:
Testing how good you are memorizing Italian, German and French names of songs and composers. Hell you even need to remember the name of the architect who built something at the Brussel's World Fair.
But you can learn a great deal about 20th century music (eg. impressionism/primitivism) which is seldom taught at middle schools.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has very good intonation and delivery skills. I just wish he stops spamming advertisements of concerts for about 20 minutes at the beginning of each lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is a standard killer course.
Not getting 70% overall would result in a D!!! x.x
Two of my friends who achieved level 8 music theory and also studied this course seriously got B+ at most.
For some reason, the professor has stopped giving out good grades this year.
reviews.comment_workload: Adequately light workload, only need to chur the concert report.

reviews.author: Sweetheart
reviews.comment_content:
Pretty much stuffs about Classical music in the Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, and 20th century music, including prominent composers and their works.

No prior music knowledge is required, it says. But actually they can be quite helpful in learning and writing concert report.
reviews.comment_teaching: For me, he's good. He cracks jokes once in a while. But his lectures can be quite boring sometimes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Self-tests : just be sure to complete them and you'll get full credits.

Participation : 10 random attendance-taking.

Midterm : easier to score above mean and sd compared to finals(mean â‰ˆ70/90), i think , as some students aren't that prepared. The contents and the questions are also easier smh. So be sure to do as good as possible!

Concert report : only one throughout the course. You can even attend free concerts at HKUST. Make sure NOT to copypaste or write things he could find on the internet. And be specific.

Final : more questions than midterm. Make sure to memorize EVERYTHING on the lecture notes and listening materials. Do the practice questions.Final scores aren't distributed but I think students work more on finals so the mean will be higher. Make sure to make as few mistakes as possible to get a good grade.

Be careful bcs this whole course is just about memorization and many people will do good!
reviews.comment_workload:
Self tests every few weeks.
Concert report submitted only until the end of the course.

reviews.author: Princess
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Was from time to time a bit boring and you need to attend the lectures all the time because he takes random attendance.
reviews.comment_grading: Very nice. However, the mean is high, so you need to study if you want a good grade. :)
reviews.comment_workload: Very light. All you have to do is going over the ppt slides before a few nights before the exam. There are a few online assessments but you don't need to get all of them correct to get the full score. As long as you finish them, you get the grade.

reviews.author: Asfand
reviews.comment_content: Provides an overview of the development of classical music from its simplest stages in the middle ages to its complex and varied form today. Covers a huge variety of composers. Highly recommended for anyone with an interest in classical music or music in general even.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor explains things from the ground up for people with no musical background and often reviews content from previous classes at the start of the lecture to ease students into new content.
reviews.comment_grading: The mean for the exams in the class tend to be around 70% . With a couple days of preparation, it is easy to score far beyond this mean. Questions on the exams sometimes appear on the self tests during the term.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. No homework. Self tests on canvas occasionally that only require participation. One concert report of 500-600 words is part of the class but one can even attend on campus concerts to fulfill this requirement.

reviews.author: vbuscartaxi
reviews.comment_content:
classical music from different age medieval , renaisance, baroque, romantic, calssical20 century
just listen music and some facts/background history of diferent age

need to do music report
attain intimacy of creativity(spring)
midterm+final

it's ok to have no music backgrond

if you wanna know what songs/music will be taught, just search huma1102 on youtube, then you can find playlist of all songs in the course
reviews.comment_teaching: quite interesting, sometimes we may also sing together
reviews.comment_grading:
easy course, high mean, wrong a few = 1 sub grade
not very good, fair grading
reviews.comment_workload: no workload, only lmes self-test which only count participation only

reviews.author: kentanggoreng
reviews.comment_content: It was rather useless for people who don't have any interest for classical music, really (a lot of people take this course just because of the good grading it promises)
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Tommasini teaches quite well, he tried to make things interesting (although he fails quite miserably sometimes). Lectures consist of him talking, video watching, and music listening.
reviews.comment_grading: I found him to give out really good grades. He gave a lot of exercises on LMES and almost everything showed up on the exam later on. If you spend time on memorising things you can easily get B or above.
reviews.comment_workload: The only thing troublesome for this course is the final essay, as you have to go to a concert and analyze what you watched to what you have learned in the course. Otherwise, the assignments are pretty decent.

reviews.author: Songhao ZHU
reviews.title: Deserves Waiting
reviews.comment_content:
Overall: Good.

The content is prepared in the form of ppt(in class)/pdf(on LMES). Detailed and well-organized, they are really excellent material for preview and review. Do NOT bother to buy textbook, for the professor will cover all the necessary content on the lecture.

Just KEEP listening, that's all. Be quite.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite nice. Standard English, and no difficulties following his idea.

Sometimes a little bit faster. But that's quite OK, remember to check the material from time to time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Adequately good.  

Midterm is rather important, and try to keep any problem (MC) done right. Loosing to much points in the midterm will affect the final grade.

DO NOT deal with the concert report WITHOUT any specified topic which is essential in grading and evaluation.
reviews.comment_workload: Light.

reviews.author: dkdkdk
reviews.title: Recommended for final year students who just need to fill in credits for HUMA
reviews.comment_content:
Music in the Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Post-tonal era

- Includes the development of opera throughout as well

Textbook
Greenberg, Robert. (2011) How to listen to great
music: its history, culture, and heart. Plume.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alright, more free-style.
He is pretty humorous.
I don't have much music background and it was alright to follow.
reviews.comment_grading:
I would say pretty generous.

1. Attendance (10%): Just attend
2. Listening quiz (10%): You can jot down notes about how the music sounds like and you won't have much trouble doing the quizzes. It's okay to get a few wrong
3. Review quiz (10%): Not difficult, just be careful not to miss any like I did
4. Midterm (20%): Average was 70/100
5. Final Exam (30%): Average was 51.8/76
6. Video Essay (20%): If you spend a lot of time making it look nice, put a lot of effects and do NOT neglect any points the professor said to mention, then you'll be fine (Average: 49/50)
reviews.comment_workload:
Midterm: done on canvas
Final: closed book. For the essay question, just make sure you know most information by heart and is able to write it down.

Listening quizzes: At least listen to the 'chorus' part 2 times and write some notes about how you would recognize the piece. (Ex. trumpets, strong entrance, violin tr, etc.)

Video essay: I spent around 15 hrs+ on the video essay to really become familiarize with Adobe video editing. I put in a lot of effort and got 50/50 for the video essay. Don't start the assignment the day before, I guarantee will take up a lot of time if you're aiming for a good score.

If you're aiming for A+, you would have to put a lot of effort. I would say A+ (Abs grading >= 98%) is pretty difficult to aim for.
However, if you are aiming for a B ~ A-, just make sure to spend enough time reviewing the materials just like you do in other courses and you will be fine.

reviews.author: AngieL
reviews.comment_content:
Take attendance randomly (10 times only)

Introduce different periods including the characteristics and some famous pieces. The syllabus is covered from Medieval music to contemporary art music
reviews.comment_teaching:
Boring but you can enjoy the music during lesson
Very easy to get angry if sb talk a little bit loud and he will immediately stop the class

reviews.author: laaaaaaa
reviews.title: A course that a regret taking the most!!!!!!!!!!!!
reviews.comment_content: All about memorising things. It's more like a history lesson of music from medieval age to modern music. I will say if u MEMORISE all the 70-80 songs from the course include the title, composer, techniques in each songs. You will surely get an A. LOL
reviews.comment_teaching: Very boring, we have to sing along with the professor almost every lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Work very hard to memorise things but poor grade. Absolute grading. But in this course, even though you work hard, it is not guaranteed to get good grade. Get a D at the end.
10 attendance randomly taken .
reviews.comment_workload:
Have to write a concert report after attending a musical event.
Beside that, there are 5 online quizzes total, all open notes. Really have to study hard or you will have to search those musical terms in the powerpoint like crazy.

reviews.author: Viviangan
reviews.comment_content: Too many content even for a student who know about classical music. You have to memorize whole trend of music and even be able to recognize the song. Too hard!!
reviews.comment_teaching: he just talking on his own. But basically you can follow if you try very hard. And he will take attendance radomly. Also you even have to attend some additional talk to get the credit!
reviews.comment_grading: Not bad
reviews.comment_workload: HUGE!!! coz you have online quizes every months and it is nearly 40 question. And you still got midterm and esaay about 1000 words and also a super hard final exam

reviews.author: keung janice
reviews.comment_content: The content include too many things that you are not able to memorize all before exam unless you just study for this course. You have to be able to identify more than 40 classical music pieces in final exam and have to be extremely familiar with the background of each piece. In conclusion, unless you want to be an expert in music history, do not take this course. Music background will not help in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: He just read the power point.
reviews.comment_grading: It is not a good grade common core course.
reviews.comment_workload: There are 5 online quiz throughout the semester.  Exams are in MC format.

reviews.author: tuisiujeh
reviews.comment_content: U learn about music from different periods, i.e medieval, renaissance, baroque, classical, romantic and twentieth century
reviews.comment_teaching: Actually pretty decent. Every lecture he will show us videos to listen to , sometimes he will even play the piano himself and ask us to sing together lol
reviews.comment_grading: Absolute grading so no comment. I got A- while missing one attendance.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much workload if you can memorise things easily.
5 online quizzes which everyone easily get full marks
and the concert report you just need to apply concepts you learned during his class. Previous music knowledge although not required will help.

reviews.author: Brady
reviews.comment_content: contents includes almost everything from medieval period all the way to the 20th century music. mainly a outline, music history based on composers. Tommasini is quite interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: pretty good. almost everything tested in midterm and final is covered in lectures. everything is demonstrated in class through his steinway( most attracting point).
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is based on absolute grades.
>=98 A+
92~98 A
90~92 A-
88~90 B+
etc.
almost impossible to get an A+. But a range is attainable, but needs quite a lot effort.
reviews.comment_workload:
we can a midterm and final test. midterm has 100 MC and you are supposed to finish it in 60(a bit challenging), final 150 MC in 90min.
5 online quizes distributed evenly among the semester, but you can do them open note.
you are supposed to attend a concert during the semester, and finish a concert report which takes up 15% towards total grading.(not very easy, but tommasini offers instructions which may help)
also 20 lectures will be randomly selected for attendance.

reviews.author: LW
reviews.title: Classic Classical Music
reviews.comment_content:
Dark Ages/ Medieval
Renaissance
Baroque
Classical Period
Romantic
20th Century

Students without prior music background should be able to handle the course.
However, students with some extent of music experience (especially those participated in an orchestra) may find the course even more interesting.

Apart from regular lectures, students are required to REGISTER and ATTEND at least one CONCERT (on the approved list of the course) during the semester. Afterwards, a short concert report is required to be submitted at the last lecture.




Personal Comment:
(This would be the ideal case)
Find a friend, you both have some extent of music knowledge.
Attend lectures together and laugh together which results in a happy semester.

If you attend the course alone, you may be bored sometimes as some topics are rather plain and boring (e.g. ballet for me).
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is extremely passionate in teaching and very willing to help students at any time.

During lectures, the professor will sometimes ask the whole lecture to sing together. It is quite fun.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute Grading
98-100%    A+
92-97.99% A
90-91.99% A-
88-89.99% B+
82â€“87.99% B
80â€“81.99% B-
78â€“79.99% C+
72â€“77.99% C
70â€“71.99% C+
60â€“69.99% D
0 â€“ 59.99% F

40% Final
25% Midterm
15% Concert Report
10% Online Quizzes
10% Attendance

Getting A+ is extremely difficult for this course, but an A-range is rather easy indeed. As long as you pay attention during lectures and do revise the lecture notes regularly, exams should be fine for every time.

Exams are in MC form with general questions and listening question. Small, random details are asked very often so do go through every bit of the lecture notes.

The GOOD news would be exams are NOT cumulative. Most stuff covered in the midterm would not appear in the final except those really basic and crucial one.

WARNING:
Do not leave your concert report til the very end, you will probably screw it up like I did (score = mean). It cost me a sub-grade from A- to B+ (so sad).
reviews.comment_workload:
Little workload, no homework at all.
Remember to finish all 5 online OPEN BOOK quizzes.

Allocate enough time to revise lecture notes regularly according to your own "music sense". ( I just did my revision right before exams and still came up with ok-ish results.)

reviews.author: Meredith13
reviews.comment_content: It covers the Medivial, Baroque, Classical, Romantic and the 20th century period. Characteristics of the pieces in specific period and the biography of composers will be discussed.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is friendly and nice. The contents were presented clearly in class. He also played musical pieces and sometimes videos to help you understand in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Concert Report 15%
The professor put great emphasis on the thesis statement of the report. You can send your thesis statement to the professor and ask if the direction is correct or not. This concert report requires precise and concise language and most importantly, the application of course concepts. There are many concerts held by the HKUST Music Alive regularly and they are free of charge. Classical concerts held by other organizations are also allowed but you have to ask the TA whether they are suitable or not.

Midterm Exam 25%
It consists of 90 MCs but the time given is one hour only. The midterm is divided into part 1 and 2. Part 1 consists of theory questions while part 2 are listening questions. Each listening sample will be played twice. However, you have to be really familiar with the ppt as time is really tight in the midterm. Try to get familiar with the listening samples earlier as you won't be able to log in to the music library server before the midterm if too many students have already logged in.

Final Exam 40%
The format is the same as the midterm exam except it is longer and non-cumulative. A Youtube playlist consisting the listening samples will be given before the exam. You can loop the playlist. I think it is easier to identify the listening samples in the Final exam than the midterm but there are many more pieces.

Attendance 10%
Attendance is taken by PRS randomly in classes but the professor allows students to write their names on a piece of paper at the end of the lesson if you have forgotten to bring it.

Online Self-tests 10%
There are 5 self- tests on Canvas. It only counts participation but not accuracy. Some exam questions are taken from the self- tests so they are good revision materials.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is mild and the atmosphere of the lessons are cozy and relax. I think it is suitable for students who have good memory as there are quite many information to recite. However, the questions in exams are straight forward and simple. I guess you could get a good garde if you recite hard and hand in the assignments on time.

reviews.author: qwerty12345
reviews.comment_content:
They could be separated into two parts. One is for musical knowledge. Another one is musical history ranging from Ars Nova to the 20th century.

Also, there would be listening skills such as how to find out the meter in a piece of music.

It is alright for people with no musical knowledge before to attend this course. You just need to have a good memory and pay attention to musical style in videoes and clips.

I believed that some content is skipped as there were not enough time.
reviews.comment_teaching: No phone or social media is allowed during his classes. Teaching may sometimes be boring, but acceptable. Overall I can feel his passion for music.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes on reading assignments 25%
Extended quizzes (x2 â†’12.5% each) 25%
Final paper (comparative listening assignment) 35%
Attendance & participation 15%

I got A in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light for this course. There is no midterm or final exam or even group project in this course. Just 6 class quizzes, 2 extended quizzes which is in mid and at the end of the semester which contained 4 quizzes each. The final assignment is a writing assignment which you need to listen and compare 2 music. The music ranging from Ars Nova to the Romantic period. You need to know the similarity and difference between the two music such as instrument they used ot the structure.
